in most cases , skies laws mirror those that govern the world ’s oceans . oceans belong to all but those near landmasses , which are managed in a similar manner to the country ’s land-bound borders . as a result , sky is usually conceptualized . airliners and fighter planes operate in “ controlled ” air close to the ground , while nationality is supposedly meant to matter less the higher you go . fragile treaties covering this are enforced mostly by the fact that few nations can afford to place assets that are high .

london – after the 2008 global financial crisis , a consensus emerged that the public sector had a responsibility to bail out systemically important banks and stimulate economic growth . but that consensus proved short-lived , and soon came to view the public sector ’s economic interventions as the root cause of the crisis , and thus needed to be reversed . this turned out to be a grave mistake . in europe , in particular , governments lambasted for their high debts , even though private debt , not public borrowing , caused the collapse . many were instructed to introduce austerity rather than stimulate growth with counter-cyclical policies .

ramallah – israeli prime minister benjamin netanyahu ’s decision to approve new jewish settlements on the eve of a possible settlement freeze is the latest round in a cycle that has been repeated so many times over the last 40 years that it would seem mundane if it were not so dangerous . the cycle goes something like this : american or international pressure mounts on israel to stop settlement activities in the occupied territories . israeli settlers and their supporters then gather even more energy to expand onto more palestinian land , build more exclusively jewish settlements , and destroy more arab homes before so-called “ freeze ” comes into effect . the peace process , not surprisingly , becomes a joke while this happens . eventually , world subsides and freeze fail to materialize .
san francisco – there is a big difference between the federal reserve ’s mandate to keep “ stable prices ” – as enunciated in the federal reserve act – and the fed ’s self-selected 2 % annual inflation target . so how is it that policymakers have managed to substitute the latter for the former ? the term “ stable prices ” is self-explanatory : a bundle of goods will cost the same ten , 50 , or even 100 years from now . by contrast , if a country experiences 2 % inflation over a ten-year period , the same items that a $ 100 can buy today will cost $ 122 at the end of the decade . after 100 years , the price tag will be a whopping $ 724 .

princeton – for the last century , economic-policy debate has been locked in orbit around respective roles and virtues of state and market . does market control of the state , in the sense that it sets limits on governments ’ ability to borrow ? or does the state take charge when the market fails to perform socially necessary functions – for example , fighting wars or maintaining full employment ? this old debate is at the heart of today ’s profound divisions over how europe should respond to its debt crisis . the same question is dividing american politics in the lead-up to november ’s presidential and congressional elections .

today , massive investments in critical infrastructure , industrial expansion , and urban development – vital to accommodate an expanding global population , set to reach nine billion by 2050 – are being made without adequate regard for disaster risk . in the absence of a comprehensive effort to protect these new economic assets , disaster-related costs will skyrocket in the coming decades . in this sense , climate-change forecasts should challenge policymakers and business leaders to re-calibrate their perceptions of exposure and disaster risk . decision-makers must recognize that there is no such thing as a natural disaster ; there is only the catastrophic impact of natural hazards on infrastructure , including workplaces , homes , roads , schools , and hospitals . following the 2004 indian ocean tsunami – which devastated 11 countries ’ coastlines , resulting in more than 150,000 deaths , a half-million injuries , and more than $ 10 billion in damages – 168 governments agreed to the hyogo framework for action ( hfa ) , a comprehensive ten-year plan for disaster risk reduction .

new york – hurricane harvey has left in his wake upended lives and enormous property damage , estimated at $ 150-180 billion . but the rains that inundated texas coast for the better part of a week , and the hurricane that is about to hit south florida , are also raising deep questions about the united states ’ economic system and politics . it is ironic , of course , that an event so related to climate change would occur in a state that is home to so many climate-change deniers – and where the economy depends so heavily on the fossil fuels that drive global warming . of course , no particular climate event can be directly related to the rise of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere . but scientists have long predicted that such increases would boost not just average temperatures , but also weather variability – and especially the occurrence of extreme events like hurricane harvey .

parfit ’s response to this line of argument leads him to make a claim that is perhaps bolder than his defense of objectivism in ethics . he considers three leading theories about what we should do – one deriving from kant , one from the social-contract tradition of hobbes , locke , rousseau , and contemporary philosophers john rawls and t.m. scanlon , and one from bentham ’s utilitarianism – argues that kantian and social-contract theories must be revised to be defensible . he then argues that these revised theories coincide with a particular form of “ “ amorphous entialism , ” a theory that is the same broad family as utilitarianism . if parfit is right , there is much less disagreement between apparently conflicting moral theories than we all thought . defenders of each of these theories are , in parfit ’s vivid phrase , “ climbing the same mountain on different sides . ”

tokyo – hillary clinton ’s recent trip to asia may one day be viewed as the most significant visit to the region by the united states diplomat since henry kissinger ’s secret mission to beijing in july 1971 . kissinger ’s mission triggered a diplomatic revolution . the revival of us-chinese relations shifted the global balance of power at the height of the cold war , preparing the way for china to open its economy – a decision that , more than any other , defined today ’s world . what clinton did , and said during her asian tour , will mark either the end of an era that kissinger initiated four decades ago , or the start of a distinct new phase in that epoch . clinton ’s tour produced the clearest signals yet that america is reluctant to accept china ’s push for regional hegemony .

indonesia argues that a nation ’s right to control all information on locally discovered viruses should be protected through the same mechanisms that the united nations food and agriculture organization uses to guarantee poor countries ’ ownership rights and patents on the seeds of its indigenous plants . under the fao ’s seed treaty , a nation can register plants , share their seeds , and derive profits from the resulting products . this useful policy reduces exploitative practices that sometimes enable multinational corporations and wealthy governments to extract outrageous profits from indigenous agriculture . it is dangerous folly , however , to extend this policy to viruses . if the concept of “ viral sovereignty ” was applied to hiv 25 years ago , we would not have the central repositories of thousands of varieties of hiv today ; these allow researchers to test drugs and vaccines against all the different strains of the virus that causes aids .

the prevailing view is that the downward trend largely reflects the fall in equilibrium or “ natural ” interest rates , driven by changes in saving and investment fundamentals . in other words , a higher propensity to save in emerging economies , together with investors ’ growing preference for safe assets , has boosted the supply of saving worldwide , even as weak growth prospects and heightened uncertainty in advanced economies have depressed investment demand . this perceived decline in “ natural ” interest rates is viewed as the key to economic recovery , because it impedes the capacity of monetary policy to provide sufficient stimulus by pushing real rates below equilibrium levels , owing to the zero lower bound on nominal rates . how to stem the decline in equilibrium rates has thus become the subject of lively debate . conspicuously absent from the debate , however , the role of financial factors in explaining the trend of the decline in real rates is the role of financial factors .

the second reason to avoid imf intervention in europe is that lending to a potentially insolvent country has serious implications for the fund . for starters , taking the imf ’s own preferred creditor status at face value , an imf loan would entail substituting its “ non-defaultable ” debt for “ defaultable ” debt with private bondholders , because the fund ’s money is used primarily to service outstanding bonds . as a result , a group of lucky bondholders would be bailed out at the expense of those that have become junior to imf debt , and remain highly exposed to a likely restructuring . because a “ haircut ” can be imposed only on whatever is left of the defaultable private debt , the larger the imf share , the deeper the haircut needed to restore sustainability . for the same reason , imf loans can be a burdensome legacy from a market perspective .

new york – the global recession now underway is the result not only of a financial panic , but also of more fundamental uncertainty about the future direction of the global economy . consumers are pulling back from home and automobile purchases not only because they have suffered a blow to their wealth with falling stock prices and housing values , but also because they are not sure where to turn . should they risk buying a new car when gasoline prices might soar again ? will they be able to put food on the table after this year ’s terrifying rise in food prices ? decisions about business investment are even starker .

ten-year treasury bonds now yield just 2.5 % , and the us federal funds rate is now on the ten-year treasury bond to yield . with the current inflation rate above 2 % and markets anticipating a similar inflation rate over the longer term ( as measured by five-year five-year-forward inflation expectations ) , ten-year treasury yields on ten-year treasury bonds should be above 4 % . a rise in ten-year yields to 4 % would reduce the value of those bonds substantially . other long-term bonds – both government bonds and corporate bonds – would suffer a similar declines . reaching the yield level has also narrowed credit spreads between higher-grade bonds and riskier domestic and emerging-market bonds .

in some sense , a market economy is gift-exchange system ; money merely tracks the value of gifts that we give one another . as a result , a market economy encourages specialization : we become very good at a narrow set of skills or products , and exchange them for millions of other things that we have no clue about how to do or make . as a result , we end up doing remarkably few things and buying everything else from others . this observation is as true of an individual as it is about the eu , whether the eu is a neighborhood , a city , a state or province , or a country . every city has grocery stores , beauty parlors , gas stations , and movie theaters that serve the local community .

inevitably , the interest-rate premium that the market would demand from a young sovereign like scotland could be minimized by issuing sterling debt , thereby protecting investors from additional devaluation risk . but , without its own currency-issuing central bank , scotland would forego seigniorage ( the profits from central-bank operations that typically benefit the national treasury ) . perhaps more important , it would have no lender of last resort capable of stabilizing the banking and financial system in crisis . all things considered , an independent scotland would be best served by issuing its own national currency from the outset , empowering scotland ’s national bank to set interest rates according to domestic economic conditions . by allowing for exchange-rate flexibility , this approach would also enable the central bank to avoid the twin hazards that arise in a currency union : undervaluation , which generates inflationary pressure , and overvaluation that demands wrenching internal devaluations ( driving down real wages ) .

beijing – financial repression – government policies that create an environment of low or negative real interest rates , with the goal of generating cheap financing for public spending – has long been a key feature of chinese economic policy . but , with funding costs for enterprises trending up , this is finally starting to change . early this year , the state council , china ’s cabinet , made funding costs less expensive for businesses , especially small and medium-size enterprises ( smes ) , a top priority . for its part , the people ’s bank of china ( pboc ) engaged in cautious monetary loosening , which includes freeing up more lending funds by banks that allocate a certain proportion of their total loan portfolio to small and medium-size enterprises ( smes ) . the pboc , through its “ pledged supplementary lending program , ” also began lending directly to banks that pledged to use social-housing funds .

berkeley – advances in artificial intelligence and robotics are powering a new wave of automation , with machines matching or outperforming humans in a fast-growing array of tasks , including some requiring complex cognitive capabilities and advanced degrees . this process has outpaced experts ’ expectations ; not surprisingly , its possible adverse effects on both quantity and quality of employment have raised serious concerns . to listen to president donald trump ’s administration , one might think that trade remains the primary reason for the loss of manufacturing jobs in the united states . trump ’s treasury secretary , steven mnuchin , has declared that the potential technological displacement of workers is “ not even on [ the administration ’s ] radar screen . ” among economists , however , the consensus is that about 80 % of the lost jobs in american manufacturing over the last three decades were a product of labor-saving and productivity-enhancing technological change , with trade coming a distant second .
berkeley – back in the late 1980 ’s , japan seemingly could not have done the wrong thing in economists ’ eyes . they saw a clear edge in japan ’s competitiveness relative to the north atlantic across a wide range of high-tech precision and mass-production industries in tradable goods . they also saw an economy that , since reconstruction began after world war ii , greatly outperformed european economies ’ expected growth . and they saw an economy growing at a much faster pace than north atlantic economies had when they possessed the same absolute and relative economy-wide productivity levels . the safe bet in the late 1980 ’s seemed to be that mechanization , computerization , and robotization would continue .

economics is not the kind of science in which there could ever be one true model that works best in all contexts . the point is not “ to reach a consensus about which model is right , ” as romer puts it , but to figure out which model applies best in a given setting . and doing so will always remain craft , not science , especially when the choice has to be made in real time . the social world differs from the physical world , because it is man-made , and hence almost infinitely malleable . so , unlike in the natural sciences , economics advances scientifically not by replacing old models with better ones , but by expanding its library of models , with each shedding light on another social contingency .

what demographers call the total fertility rate is the average number of live births per woman over her lifetime . in the long run , a population is said to be stable if the tfr is at replacement rates , a figure that is slightly above 2.3 for the world as a whole , and somewhat lower , at 2.1 for developed countries , reflecting their lower infant-mortality rates . the tfr for most developed countries now stands well below replacement levels . the oecd average is at around 1.74 , but some countries , including germany and japan , produce less than 1.4 children per woman . the largest tfr declines in recent years , however , in developing countries .
by 2004 , there were more than one billion subscribers to gsm services worldwide . the global reach of regulation implied huge economies of scale in handsets and network hardware , so prices fell rapidly , and interoperability between networks and across countries was much easier to achieve . many regulations play this standard-setting role . contrary to the simplistic view that regulation inevitably is bad for business , there are actually three important channels through which regulation can benefit the economy . one is the market-creating and market-growing role illustrated by gsm .

geneva – the world ’s refugee crisis is most often measured in numbers . but for young refugees missing out on education , the crisis can also be tracked by an irreversible metric : passage of time . of the 17.2 million people that the united nations high commissioner for refugees ( the un refugee agency ) is responsible for protecting , roughly half are under the age of 18 , meaning that an entire generation of young people , already robbed of their childhood , could lose out on a future just as well . school-age children form a large share of the world ’s displaced population . at the end of 2016 , an estimated 11.6 million refugees were lifted out of “ protracted displacement ” : they were away from their homes for more than five years , and have no “ immediate prospects ” of return .

it is too soon to discount genetics , however , because the science of “ epigenetics ” – the study of mechanisms for turning genes on and off , thereby altering how a cell develops without altering the genetic code – is gaining traction . indeed , the 2012 nobel prize in medicine was awarded to john gurdon and shinya yamanaka for revolutionizing scientists ’ understanding of how cells develop by reprogramming dna and cells without altering their genetic structure . in 1962 , gurdon ’s finding that almost any cell in the body contains the complete dna code allowed him to create a tadpole by cloning an adult frog . more than four decades later , in 2006 , yamanaka discovered a way to trick complex adult cells in mice into regressing to their immature state , forming stem cells . before this , stem cells – which can potentially be reprogrammed to develop into replacements for lost or damaged tissue – could be taken only from early-stage embryos , a practice that fueled ethical controversy .

according to the most up-to-date estimate by the late economic historian angus maddison , china ’s per capita gdp in 2008 was $ 6,725 in 1990 , which amounted to 21 % of per capita gdp in the united states . that is roughly the same gap that existed between the us and japan in 1951 , singapore in 1967 , taiwan in 1975 , and south korea in 1977 – four economies that are also among the 13 successful economies studied by the growth commission . harnessing their latecomer advantage , japan ’s average annual growth rate soared to 9.2 % in the subsequent 20 years , compared to 8.6 % in singapore , 8.3 % in taiwan , and 7.6 % in south korea . if the latecomer ’s advantage implied by the income gap between the four nies and the us allowed nies to realize average annual gdp growth rates of 7.6 % for 20 years , china ’s annual growth potential should be equivalent to 8 % for the 2008-2028 period . to realize its potential growth as a latecomer , china needs , above all , to deepen its market-oriented reforms

london – next week , governments will gather in warsaw , poland , for a crucial round of climate negotiations , with both expectations and ambition running at an all-time low . but this need not be the case : the warsaw meeting provides an opportunity to galvanize action on one of the most potent forces driving climate change – the billions of dollars spent by governments on fossil-fuel subsidies . warsaw talks are staging a post on the path to the 2015 united nations climate summit in paris , at which governments will seek to forge an agreement that is preventing dangerous climate change , defined as global warming of more than two degrees celsius . failure would expose future generations to catastrophic climate risks , while trapping millions of people in poverty as a result of more frequent , intense , and protracted droughts , floods , and storms . basic carbon arithmetic illustrates the scale of the problem .

in the 1930 ’s , the countries that raised their tariffs and tightened their quotas were those with the least ability to manage their exchange rates – namely , those that remained on the gold standard . in 1931 , after britain and some two dozen other countries suspended gold convertibility and allowed their currencies to depreciate , countries that stuck to the gold standard found themselves in a deflationary vice . in desperate efforts to do something – anything to defend their economies , they turned to protectionism , imposing “ exchange-rate dumping ” duties , and import quotas to offset the loss of competitiveness caused by their own increasingly overvalued currencies . but trade restrictions were poor substitutes for domestic reflationary measures , because they did little to arrest the downward spiral of output and prices . they did nothing to stabilize rickety banking systems .

after nearly 15 years of unprecedented growth – interrupted only by a brief slowdown in 2000-2001 – the united states accumulated huge stocks of foreign liabilities , equivalent to 25 % of its gdp . with the current-account deficit now exceeding 5 % of gdp , america ’s foreign debt is rising fast . but no country can accumulate debt forever – and what can not last sooner or later must end . in early 1985 , when america ’s current-account deficit reached $ 120 billion , about a third of today ’s level at current prices , the rest of the world stopped financing it . the outcome was a sudden fall in the value of the dollar , which depreciated by 50 % against the deutschemark .

cambridge – public-private cooperation or coordination is receiving considerable attention nowadays . a plethora of centers for study in business and government relations have been created , with researchers producing a large literature on how to design , analyze , and evaluate public-private partnerships . even the world economic forum has been transformed into “ an international organization for public-private cooperation . ” private-private coordination , of course , has been the essence of economics for the last 250 years . while adam smith began us on the optimistic belief that an invisible hand would take care of most coordination issues , in the intervening period , economists discovered all kinds of market failures , informational imperfections , and incentive problems that gave rise to rules , regulation , and other forms of government and societal intervention .

for better or worse , our central banks manage the quantity and flow of money by withdrawing or adding paper assets to the stock held by private banks . when they want to stimulate economic activity , central banks buy from private banks ’ commercial loans , mortgages , deposits , and other assets . the banks then have more cash to lend . and vice versa , when the authorities want to cool down the economy . but the more successful libra becomes , the more money people transfer from their bank account to their libra wallet , and the less able central banks will be to stabilize the economy .

cambridge – economics teaches that measuring the wellbeing of the individual is the quantity and variety of goods that it or she can consume . consumption possibilities are in turn maximized by providing firms with the freedom they need to take advantage of new technologies , the division of labor , economies of scale , and mobility . consumption is the goal ; production is the means . markets , rather than communities , are unit and object to analysis . no one can deny that this consumer – and market-centric vision of the economy has produced plenty of fruit .
fragmentation – meaning that the internet is ending – is a real threat . some estimates put the internet ’s economic contribution to global gdp as high as $ 4.2 trillion in 2016 . a fragmented “ splinternet ” would be very costly to the world , but that is one of the possible futures outlined last month in the global commission ’s report on internet governance , chaired by former swedish prime minister carl bildt . the internet now links nearly half the world ’s population , with another billion people – as well as some 20 billion devices – forecast to be connected in the next five years . but further expansion is not guaranteed .

unhcr , as currently conceived , is not an independent , nonpartisan agency that it claims to be . heavily dependent on donors and host governments to launch relief operations , it is beholden to its interests , and does not always have the political support it needs to get the job done . the other major multilateral migration agency , the iom , assists in the return of migrants , asylum seekers , refugees , and internally displaced to their place of origin , or to other countries or regions that have agreed to accept them . but , like unhcr , governance issues plague the iom . in particular , the iom lacks a mechanism to evaluate whether national governments are using coercion – prohibited under international law – to repatriate or relocate refugees .
with political gridlock blocking an appropriate fiscal response – the united states congress after 2008 , the federal reserve has not passed an annual budget , a basic component of responsible economic governance , for five years – central banks have been forced to strengthen economies artificially . to do so , they have relied on near-zero interest rates and unconventional measures like quantitative easing to stimulate growth and job creation . beyond being incomplete , this approach implicitly favors the wealthy , who hold disproportionately large shares of financial assets . meanwhile , companies have become increasingly aggressive in their efforts to reduce their fiscal bills , including through so-called inversions , by shifting their headquarters to lower-tax jurisdictions . as a result , most countries face trio of inequalities – income , wealth , and opportunity – that , left unchecked , reinforce one another , with far-reaching consequences .

paris – tunisia , one of the arab league ’s 22 members , is in the throes of a severe and profound crisis , albeit perhaps one with favorable resolution . it is the smallest north african country , covering 163,000 square kilometers – more or less twice the size of belgium , the netherlands , and luxembourg – and containing a population of 10.5 million . it is also full of charm and moderation in its climate , history , and culture . it was once the pillar of roman cultural dynamism and influence . the first african region to be christianized was the land of saint augustine and the main source of catholic evangelism in africa .

financial liberalization will be difficult to reverse , but its adverse side effects – including greater systemic risk – require a series of reforms . first , more information and transparency about complex assets , and who is holding them , are needed . second , complex instruments should be traded on exchanges rather than over-the-counter markets , and they should be standardized to allow liquid secondary markets to arise . third , we need better supervision and regulation of the financial system , including regulation of opaque or highly leveraged financial institutions , such as hedge funds and even sovereign wealth funds . fourth , rating agencies ’ role needs to be rethought , with more regulation and competition introduced .

now , a new paper by servaas storm effectively demolishes another famous trope of neoliberal economics : the argument that labor-market “ rigidities ” depress output and employment . one of the empirical investigations most often cited for this argument is paper by timothy besley and robin burgess , who use manufacturing data across india for the 1958-92 period . besley and burgess argued that pro-worker regulations in some states resulted in lower output , employment , investment , and productivity , and even increased urban poverty , relative to states that did not adopt such regulations . this conclusion came to underpin the conventional wisdom that labor-market regulation is harmful to industrial expansion , and that the way to increase production and employment in manufacturing is to promote more labor-market “ flexibility ” by repealing laws that protect workers . this wisdom prevailed not only in india ; it influenced policies accordingly across a wide range of developing countries .

genes can be damaged by environmental factors , such as radiation or chemicals . they can also be damaged by the products of ordinary metabolism . our bodies elaborate repair systems that maintain the integrity of our genes , even in the presence of damaging agents . occasionally , however , damage is not repaired . if the damage occurs in key genes that regulate cell growth , cancer can develop .

greece ’s economic weakness increases its current level of deficit . five years of falling gdp have depressed tax receipts and increased transfer payments . the imf estimates that these cyclical effects on revenues and outlays have raised the overall deficit by almost 5 % of greek gdp . on a cyclically adjusted basis , greece ’s overall budget would show a surplus of 0.6 % of gdp this year . this also implies that if greece could escape its current recession , its national debt would shrink , both absolutely and as a share of gdp .

the search for a new managing director of the imf provides a keen reminder of how unjust today ’s international institutions are . created in the postwar world of 1945 , they reflect realities that have long ceased to exist . the organization and allocation of power within the un , the imf , the world bank , and g7 meetings reflect a global equilibrium that disappeared long ago . after wwii germany and japan were defeated aggressors , the soviet union posed a major threat , with china engulfed in civil war that would bring mao ’s communists to power . much of the so-called third world was either recently independent or remained colonies ; all were very poor .

the odious debt idea was revived in an influential 2006 article by jayachandran and michael kremer , and a 2010 report by the center for global development ( cgd ) , which proposed that economic sanctions include a mechanism aimed at preventing the accumulation of odious obligations . the mechanism would take the form of a declaration that debt issued by a particular government would be deemed odious . in effect , this is what the trump administration has just done . such a declaration reduces the flow of funds to odious regimes , owing to the risk that successor governments renounce their predecessor ’s debts without incurring legal and reputational costs ( because participating countries ’ courts will not enforce debt contracts ) . the cgd report proposes that a regime should be considered odious if it abuses human rights , employs military coercion , perpetrates electoral fraud , and mismanages or misappropriates public funds .

rich countries ’ shift from subsistence economies to sustained growth and prosperity was conditioned on a profound demographic shift – occurring in the 19 th century in western europe and throughout the twentieth century in east asia – in which fertility rates fell dramatically . the past two decades witnessed similarly sharp fertility declines in poor countries , which are now showing solid signs of economic progress . in egypt , for example , fertility rates have declined from 4.8 to 2.9 children per woman in the last 15 years . during the past decade , egypt ’s average annual per capita income has grown at 2.6 % . during the same period , tunisia ’s population growth rate fell by more than 50 % , to slightly more than two children per woman , while per capita income has grown at an impressive annual rate of 3 % .

why are services so important to china ’s rebalancing ? for starters , services are far more labor-intensive than the country ’s traditional growth sectors . in 2011 , chinese services generated 30 % more jobs per unit of output than did manufacturing and construction . this means that the chinese economy can achieve its all-important labor-absorption goals – employment , urbanization , and poverty reduction – with much slower gdp growth than in the past . in other words , a 7-8 % growth trajectory in an increasingly services-led economy can hit the same labor-absorption targets that required 10 % growth under china ’s previous model .

paris – last month , atmospheric concentrations of carbon dioxide surpassed 400 parts per million for the first time in roughly three million years . if the current trend , which fits the worst-case scenario set by the intergovernmental panel on climate change ( ipcc ) , persists , co2 concentrations will rise above 800 ppm in the end of this century – with devastating consequences . indeed , the predicted global average temperature increase of 2.4-6.4 ° c caused by such high ambient concentrations of co2 is expected to trigger the worst outcomes foreseen in ipcc scenarios , including loss of an estimated 40 % of species , more frequent extreme weather events , and widespread water scarcity . to avoid imposing such risk and uncertainty on future generations , global carbon emissions , which stand at 8.5 gigatons annually , must be halved by 2050 . even in the ipcc ’s best-case scenario , co2 concentrations will rise to 550 ppm by the end of the century – a level that many researchers argue would already be too high to avoid dire consequences .

new york – barack obama ’s basic outlines of an approach to foreign policy became clear in 2009 . his administration believes that the united states should talk with other governments even if it disagrees profoundly with its character . it prefers acting with other countries alone . and it has shifted the focus of american foreign policy from what countries do within their borders to how they act beyond them . all of this differentiates obama from his immediate predecessor , george w. bush , whose administration branded countries as evil and mostly refused to deal with them ; often , it rejected cooperation with other governments , lest the us find itself constrained ; and it seeks to transform other countries rather than influence their actions .
until now , nations ’ wealth has been based on coal combustion , gas , and oil . but , if the 2 ° c target is taken seriously , the twenty-first century will see countries that are not so far down the path of carbonization ( such as large parts of africa ) or that leave it in time ( such as india and pakistan ) , able to become wealthy by helping societies that must de-carbonize rapidly . for the moment , all this remains utopian . in its current state , cap-and-trade schemes to reduce emissions are far from being fair and effective ; a major improvement would include establishing a central climate bank to register and supervise the transfer of emission credits . this bank would also ensure that emissions trading did not run counter to the goal of remaining within the entire global budget , for example , through the complete sale of unused emissions credits by individual developing countries at the start of the treaty .

new haven – the severity of the global financial crisis that we have seen over the past two years must do with a fundamental source of instability in the banking system , one that we can and must design from existence . to do that , we must advance the state of our financial technologies . in a severe financial crisis , banks find that the declining market value of many of their assets leaves them short of capital . they can not raise much more capital during the crisis , so , in order to restore capital adequacy , stop making new loans , and call in their outstanding loans , thereby throwing the entire economy – if not the entire global economy – into a tailspin . this problem is rather technical in nature , because it is its solution .

princeton – most of today ’s advanced economies became what they are by traveling the well-worn path of industrialization . the progression of manufacturing industries – textiles , steel , automobiles – emerged from the ashes of traditional craft and guild systems , transforming agrarian societies into urban ones . peasants became factory workers , a process that underpinned not only the unprecedented rise in economic productivity , but also the wholesale revolution in social and political organization . the labor movement led to mass politics , and ultimately to political democracy . over time , manufacturing ceded its place to services .

the trouble began at the cold war ’s end , when the collapse of bankrupt communist ideology was also very interpreted as the triumph of the market . as communism was discarded , so was the concept of the state as an agent around which our collective interests and ambitions could be organized . the individual became the ultimate agent of change – an individual conceived as the type of rational actor that populates economists ’ models . such individual identity is derived not from class interests or other sociological characteristics , but from the market logic that dictates maximization of self-interest , whether as a producer , a consumer , or a voter . indeed , economics was placed on a pedestal and enshrined in institutions like central banks and competition authorities , which were intentionally separated and made independent from politics .

washington , dc – anyone watching the united states ’ presidential race needs to understand that national opinion polls do not provide an accurate picture of how the election could turn out . thanks to america ’s electoral college , it is not who wins the most votes nationwide that matters , but who wins in which states . each state is awarded a certain number of votes in the electoral college , depending on the size of its population . the candidate who crosses the threshold of 270 electoral votes wins the presidency . in almost every state , a candidate who wins 50.1 % of the popular vote is awarded 100 % of its electoral vote .

london – a flawed understanding of what drives economic growth has emerged as the gravest threat to european recovery . european policymakers obsessively think that prosperity is synonymous with trade surpluses . this largely explains why germany routinely cited as an example of a strong , “ competitive ” economy . but economic growth , even in traditionally export-led economies , is driven by productivity growth , not by the ability to capture a growing share of global markets . while imports must of course be financed by exports , the focus on trade competitiveness is drawing attention from europe ’s underlying problem – very weak productivity growth .

new york – capital-account regulations have been at the center of global financial debates for two years . the reasons are clear : since the world has experienced a “ multi-speed recovery , ” as the international monetary fund puts it , slow-growth advanced countries are maintaining very low interest rates and other expansionary monetary policies , while rapid growth in emerging economies unwinding expansionary policies that they adopted during recessions . this asymmetry has spurred massive capital flows from the former to the latter , which are likely to continue . emerging economies worry that this flood of capital will drive up their currencies ’ exchange rates , in addition to fueling current-account deficits and asset bubbles that past experience has taught them is a sure recipe for future crises . compounding the problem , one of the countries ’ expansionary policies is the united states , which has the world ’s largest financial sector and issues the paramount global currency .

so what lessons does history have to teach us about our current global economic predicament ? in 1829 , john stuart mill made the keynesian intellectual leap in figuring out how to fight what he called “ general gluts . ” mill saw that excess demand for some particular set of assets in financial markets mirrored the excess supply of goods and services in product markets , which in turn generated excess supply of workers in labor markets . the implication of this was clear . if you relieved excess demand for financial assets , you also cured excess supply of goods and services ( the shortfall of aggregate demand ) and excess supply of labor ( mass unemployment ) .

botswana ’s incredible annual per capita income growth of roughly 13 % in the past decade was accompanied by a decline from nearly six children per woman to less than four . why is rapid population growth bad for a country ’s standard of living ? the math is simple : more people means that ( on average ) everyone gets less . a growing population dilutes not only the accumulation of physical capital , but also human capital . the quality of children in poor households goes down as their quantity goes up , because poor families with many children are unable to invest enough in each child ’s education to ensure that future adults benefit from a key determinant of economic success .

in the scandinavian countries , as opposed to , say , germany and the us , the government , not individual companies , is responsible for most social benefits . that way , economically irrational lock-in effects , whereby workers simply can not afford to change jobs , are avoided . moreover , the benefits are generous enough to ensure that the short period of unemployment does not force workers to sell their homes or even cars . the system protects not only the unemployed , who can continue to pay their mortgages and interest , but also indirectly the banks , because their loans to households are repaid even in times of recession . and , instead of solving all kinds of economic caused private problems , laid-off workers can concentrate on finding new and more future-oriented jobs .

by buying government bonds for cash , a central bank can satisfy demand and push down the price of cash . when excess demand is not excess for cash , there will be no excess supply of bonds and stocks that underpin and finance the productive capital of the economy . expansionary monetary policy , therefore , via the standard open-market operations of a central bank is the first item on the checklist of what to do in a financial crisis . three months ago , i argued that all but a tiny and unbalanced fringe of economists approve of expansionary open-market operations to keep total nominal spending constant in a downturn . i was also right to say that all but a tiny and unbalanced fringe of economists approve of central-bank guarantees of stability in order to prevent the risk of a collapse of the payments system from becoming a first-order consideration that boosts monetary demand to unnatural levels .

if the relationship between fruit fly genes and behavior is so complex , can it be any less so with humans ? the view that an individual gene could account for a complete biological trait is as old as genetics itself . whether describing genes for color flowers in pea plants or the shape of fruit fly wings , geneticists at the beginning of the last century believed that each gene governed one unique characteristic . soon , a few early geneticists , the founders of the eugenics movement , made the odious assertion that “ licentiousness , ” “ untouchatlessness , ” and “ criminality ” could all be attributed to individual genes as well . as time passed and scientific knowledge accumulated – much of it from the fruit fly – the true complexity of the relationship between genes and characteristics became clear .

greene found that people asked to make moral judgments about “ personal ” violations , like pushing the stranger off footbridge , showed increased activity in areas associated with emotions . this was not the case with people who were asked to make judgments about relatively impersonal ” violations like throwing a switch . moreover , the minority of subjects who did consider it right to push the stranger off footbridge took longer to reach that judgment than those who said that doing so would be wrong . why would our judgments , and our emotions , vary in this way ? for most of our evolutionary history , human beings – and our primate ancestors – lived in small groups in which violence could be inflicted only in an up-close and personal way , by hitting , pushing , strangling , or using a stick or stone as a club .

paris – with weak demand in advanced countries now impeding growth in emerging economies , including major players in asia and latin america , many argue that the era of income convergence has come to an end . nothing could be further from the truth . as i argued before , convergence in emerging countries ’ real average incomes , in aggregate , with advanced countries ’ incomes , is likely to continue in 2020 . that process began in the late 1980 ’s , and continued unabated , with the exception of the asian financial crisis of 1997-1998 . the pace of convergence accelerated further during , and just after the 2008-2009 global financial crisis : the aggregate average differential in per capita income growth rose to more than four percentage points in the 2008-2012 period , from a little more than two percentage points in the two decades before .

the second myth presumes that prohibition reduces the harm associated with drugs . global markets in cannabis , opium , and coca products essentially resemble other global commodities markets , yet global drug-control policies operate on the assumption that drug markets bear more in common with smallpox and other infectious diseases for which there is no demand . governments can act unilaterally and multilaterally to regulate commodity markets , but they are a mistake to view prohibition as the ultimate or maximum form of regulation . prohibition in fact represents the abdication of regulation . whatever is suppressed is effectively unregulated , except by criminal organizations .

the reason that un climate conferences keep failing is straightforward : their agendas – centered on voluntary , quantitative targets – are fundamentally flawed . agreeing to quantitative , universally applied emissions-reduction targets at the un conference is easy . but countries automatically regard adherence to those targets as sacrifice : in the effort to reduce emissions by x tons , we would lose y million jobs , with gdp falling by $ z billion . because there are no actual sanctions or punishment for non-compliance when push comes to shove , governments can simply change their minds . even if a government does try to uphold its commitments , say , by imposing new regulations on high-emitting industries , it may not obtain the desired results .

new haven – in what could well be the final act of desperation , central banks are abdicating effective control over the economies they were entrusted to manage . first came zero interest rates , then quantitative easing ( qe ) , and now negative interest rates – one futile attempt beget another . just as the first two gambits failed to gain meaningful economic traction in chronically weak recoveries , the shift to negative rates will only compound the risks of financial instability and set the stage for the next crisis . adopting negative interest rates – initially launched in europe in 2014 and now embraced in japan – represents a major turning point for central banking . previously , the emphasis was placed on boosting aggregate demand – primarily by lowering borrowing costs , but also by spurring wealth effects from appreciating financial assets .

beijing – after years of intervening to manage the renminbi ’s exchange rate , the people ’s bank of china ( pboc ) is under pressure to float the currency . but striking the right balance between loosening its grip on the exchange rate and maintaining monetary stability will not be easy . all economics students learn mundell-fleming model , according to which an economy can not maintain a fixed exchange rate , free capital movements , and independent monetary policy simultaneously . if a country with a fixed exchange rate and an open capital account tightens monetary policy to contain inflation , the rise in domestic interest rates will give market participants an incentive to borrow foreign currencies and convert them into domestic currencies for domestic investment . the resulting capital inflows , if persistent , would generate upward pressure on the currency , forcing the central bank to maintain exchange-rate stability , intervene by selling domestic currency , especially the us dollar , until interest rates and money supply returned to their former levels .
american presidential candidate hillary clinton has a more targeted proposal : a 15 % tax credit for profits that companies distribute to workers over two years . by providing temporary tax relief , the scheme would help companies offset the administrative costs of establishing profit-sharing programs . to limit costs and prevent abuse , profits totaling more than 10 % on top of the employee ’s wage would be excluded ; overall , the amount offered to individual firms would be capped ; and safeguards against substituting for profit sharing for wages , raises , and other benefits would be established . tax credit could also foster changes in corporate culture , by spurring boan/level discussions not only of profit sharing , but also of sharing information and decision-making authority with employees . stagnant incomes in most american workers undermine the demand side of economic growth ( by discouraging household consumption ) and supply side ( through adverse effects on educational opportunity , human-capital development , and innovation ) .

a second conclusion to be drawn from the current situation is that the fed has now overestimated the strength of america ’s economy for 11 consecutive years . elementary mathematics dictates that credible forecasts should at least overestimate half the time and undershoot half the time . if each year of fed forecasting were coin toss , we would now have eleven heads in row , and zero tails . the odds that this will happen are one in 2,048 . the fed clearly needs a deep look at its forecasting methodology and policymaking processes .

so the global economy should indeed be thought of as the global capitalist system . global integration has brought tremendous benefits : the international division of labor , which is so clearly proven by the theory of comparative advantage ; dynamic benefits such as scale economies and the rapid diffusion of innovations from one country to another , which are less easy to demonstrate static equilibrium theory ; and noneconomic benefits , such as freedom of choice associated with the international movement of goods , capital , and people , and the freedom of thought associated with the international movement of ideas . but global capitalism is not without problems ; we need to understand these better if we want the system to survive . by focusing on these problems , i am not trying to belittle the benefits of globalization . these benefits , i believe , can be sustained only by deliberate and persistent efforts to correct and contain the system ’s deficiencies .

new york – many historians and economists insist that we live in an age shaped by vast and impersonal forces . the actions and decisions of one man or woman , regardless of how powerful , can not determine the destiny of nations . this may be true much or most of the time . but there are moments when individual leader choices can change the course of history . that has certainly been true in russia , and it may soon turn out to be true in turkey as well .
as i show in a new peer-reviewed paper , even if successful , the paris agreement would cut temperatures by just 0.05 ° celsius in 2100 . sea-level rise would be reduced by just 1.3 centimeters , and it would be only by the highest level . this may seem surprising : we constantly hear how every country has made important commitments to reduce co2 emissions – the so-called “ intended nationally determined contributions , ” or indcs . according to the un climate chief , christiana figueres , “ indcs have the capability to limit the forecast temperature rise to around 2.7 ºc by 2100 , by no means enough but a lot lower than the estimated four , five , or more degrees of warming projected by many prior levels . ” figueres suggested that the paris agreement would cut almost 2 ° c of warming , from 4.5 ° c to 2.7 ° c. by 2015 . though her wording was crafted to avoid actually saying this , it was predictably what most people heard .

new delhi – international debate about china ’s rise has centered on its increasing trade muscle , growing maritime ambitions , and expanding capacity to project military power . one critical issue , however , usually escapes attention : china ’s rise as a hydro-hegemon with no modern historical parallel . no other country has ever managed to assume such unchallenged riparian preeminence on the continent by controlling the headwaters of multiple international rivers and manipulating their cross-border flows . china , the world ’s largest dam builder – with slightly more than half of the planet ’s 50,000 large dams – is rapidly accumulating leverage against its neighbors by undertaking massive hydro-engineering projects on transnational rivers . asia ’s water map fundamentally changed after the 1949 communist victory of china .

paris – the world is witnessing a drastic decline in its natural capital . plant and animal species are vanishing at an unprecedented pace – 100 to 1,000 times the rate of natural extinction . the planet ’s most endangered ecosystems are located in developing countries , and thus depend on some of the neediest communities in the world for conservation . conversely , the poor are the first to suffer from the deterioration of their natural environment . but in the developing world , immediate economic needs often override long-term imperatives , and protecting a fragile environment rarely take a national priority .
africa has an exceptionally rich clean-energy asset portfolio , including nearly nine terawatts of solar capacity , more than 350 gigawatts of hydropower capacity , and more than 100 gw of wind-power potential . this is more than enough to meet the continent ’s future demand . at the same time , renewable-energy sources are becoming less expensive , making them increasingly competitive with fossil-fuel alternatives . for example , the price of the “ “ monetarist solar energy ” in africa fell by 50 % between 2010 and 2014 , and continues to decline today . and south africa ’s renewable-energy independent producer procurement program has seen a total decline in bid prices and oversubscription rates .

the problem after all is not in east germany , but rather in the west . unification meant that everyone is not only the benefits of west german economic institutions – property rights and hard money – but also all disastrously negative institutions : unions , overpaying unemployment , and excessive job security , pervasive regulation . if west germany , faced with unification , rolled back all of these unaffordable limitations to free play in markets , the economic costs would have been far lower : east and west germany would have had more near-full employment , the productivity drive would have been far more aggressive . to be sure , german corporatism did not allow such a solution : unions wanted their wages to protect . the only way to secure them was for the government to pay lots of unemployment compensation in the high wage east germany .

given all this , the most critical policy question in emerging markets today is how to respond to inflows , which will inevitably drive up their exchange rates and threaten export-led growth . the first option is to do nothing , and to allow the currency to appreciate . this may be the right response if the inflows and upward exchange-rate pressures are driven by fundamental factors ( the current-account surplus , an undervalued currency , a large and persistent growth differential ) . but , in many cases , inflows are driven by short-term factors , fads , and irrational exuberance , which can lead to an overvalued currency , crowding out non-traditional export sectors or import-competing sectors , loss of competitiveness , and eventually large current-account deficits and thus tighter external constraints on growth . this problem is exacerbated by the fact that the world ’s largest exporter , china , is aggressively intervening to minimize any appreciation of the renminbi .

because many contracts are “ sticky ” ( that is , not easily revised ) in monetary terms , inflation and deflation would both inflict damage on the economy . rising prices reduce the value of savings and pensions , while falling prices reduce profit expectations , encourage hoarding , and increase the real burden of debt . keynes ’s dictum became the ruling wisdom of monetary policy ( one of his few to survive ) . governments , conventional wisdom suggests , should aim for stable prices , with a modest bias toward inflation to stimulate businessmen ’ “ animal spirits ” and shoppers . in the ten years prior to the 2008 financial crisis , independent central banks set the inflation target of around 2 % to provide price-stability economies .

the idea behind a slippery slope is that if you do x , which is acceptable , you end up doing y , which is not . indeed , two types of slippery slopes – logical and sociological – exist . on the logical slippery slope , you slide to the bottom and embrace morally unacceptable , because there is no way to distinguish it from acceptable practice . you can slide down the sociological slippery slope from one practice to another – even if the two are conceptually different – just because the existence of one creates a social climate receptive to another . therapeutic cloning is conceptually distinct from reproductive cloning .

any economist who seems to question the benefits of trade openness risks banishment , so let me be clear : i do not question the standard version of gains-from-trade theory , but the extravagant , unwarranted claims made about the consequences of openness . for the latter endangers broad public acceptance of the actual article because it unleashes expectations that are unlikely to be fulfilled . in the real world , opening up is not a simple matter of revising tariff codes and removing barriers to foreign investment . it requires a heavy dose of institutional reform that consumes financial , bureaucratic , and political resources . while many institutional reforms are development-friendly , they may not be targeted at key developmental goals – growth , improved governance , industrial and technological capability , poverty alleviation – and occasionally divert attention from them .

indian-style socialism was a compound of nationalism and idealism . it embodied the conviction that goods and services vital to indians ’ economic well-being must remain in indian hands – and not in indians ’ hands seeking to profit from producing and selling such goods and services , but rather disinterested state hands , father , and mother to all indians . given this mindset , performance was not an appropriate criterion for judging the public sector ’s utility . inefficiencies were masked by generous subsidies from the national treasury , and a combination of vested interests – socialist ideologues , bureaucratic managers , trade unions , and monopolies – kept it beyond political criticism . the “ permit-quota ” culture of statist socialism allowed politicians and bureaucrats to use public services as a vehicle for private gratification , giving birth to a culture of corruption that still persists .

cambridge – the united states is famous for its ability to innovate . aspiring fiscal conservatives around the world thus might be interested in learning four tricks that american politicians commonly use when promising to cut taxes while simultaneously cutting budget deficits . these are tough promises to keep , for the simple reason that a budget deficit equals government spending minus tax revenues . but each of the four tricks has been refined over three decades . indeed , they first acquired their colorful names in the early years of ronald reagan ’s presidency : the “ magic asterisk , ” the “ rosy scenario , ” the laffer hypothesis , and the “ starve the beast ” scenario .

hong kong – next month , policymakers , business leaders , academics , and civil-society representatives will meet in kiel , germany , for the global economic symposium ( ges ) , where they will attempt to develop concrete solutions to today ’s most pressing economic issues . whether they produce effective proposals will depend on a comprehensive understanding of the factors underpinning – and undermining – financial stability worldwide . at last year ’s summit , dialogues about the future of central banking , which pitted inflation-targeting against financial stability , produced three solutions : central banks should adopt a counter-cyclical policy approach ; a world monetary authority should be created to promote multilateral cooperation among central banks ; and price stability must remain central banks ’ primary goal . while these solutions have some merit , they are inadequate to address effectively the complex and far-reaching flaws that led to the 2007-2009 global financial crisis . the crisis represented a comprehensive systemic failure , involving breakdowns at almost all levels , from macroeconomic theory to micro-level incentives to institutions .
piketty ’s framework highlights several drivers of this trend . for starters , by lowering trade and investment barriers , globalization has created a winner-take-all environment in which the most technologically advanced actors have gained market share through economies of scale . in particular , as the global economy moves toward knowledge-based value creation , a few innovators in global branding , high-technology , and creative industries win big , with the global tech boom augmenting their gains . the resulting concentration of income , wealth , and power undermines systemic stability by creating too-big-to-fail entities , while hampering smaller players ’ ability to compete . the global financial system reinforces this concentration , with negative real interest rates promoting financial repression on household saving .
prevention , however , must also address the dangers posed by potentially destabilizing capital movements . recent experience teaches that the speed and magnitude with which both domestic and foreign investors can move into and out of capital markets far exceeds individual countries ’ ability – and the international community – to counter such flows . many countries lack foreign currency reserves sufficient to meet sudden and large-scale capital outflows without destabilizing their domestic economies . sometimes these outflows can occur through no fault of the country in question , but because of financial-market contagion that spreads from disturbances elsewhere . all this phenomenon was too evident during the asian crisis and following the russian debt default of august 1998 .

under heavy pressure from america , china ’s leaders agreed in principle to float the renminbi , but refuse to say when . a floating currency is inevitable because china liberalizes its capital market and eliminates restrictions on international capital movements ; otherwise , china would have to surrender control over its money supply and interest rates to the us . yet china ’s rulers are right to postpone the decision to float . the chinese can delay , but they can not hide from a fundamental economic law : if the two countries ’ exchange rate is fixed and capital flows are unrestricted , the economically dominant one will exercise control over other countries ’ monetary policies . because the dollar is the world ’s dominant reserve currency , and america ’s fed controls the supply of us dollars , as long as china sticks to a fixed exchange rate , it can not control its own money supply .

consider the first claim that the dollar ’s status as a reserve currency protects it , because governments around the world need to hold dollars as foreign exchange reserves . the problem is that foreign holdings of dollar securities are no longer primarily “ foreign exchange reserves ” in the traditional sense . in earlier decades , countries held dollars because they needed to have highly liquid and widely accepted currency to bridge the financing gap if their imports exceeded their exports . the obvious candidate for this reserve fund was america ’s treasury bills . but , since the late 1990s , countries like south korea , taiwan , and singapore have accumulated very large volumes of foreign reserves , reflecting both export-driven growth strategies and a desire to avoid a repeat of the speculative currency attacks that triggered the 1997-1998 asian financial crisis .

countries would be well advised not to include pari passu clauses in future debt contracts , at least without specifying more fully what is intended . such contracts should also include collective-action clauses , which make it impossible for vulture funds to hold up debt restructuring . when a sufficient share of creditors agree to a restructuring plan ( in argentina ’s case , holders of more than 90 % of the country ’s debt did ) , others can be forced to go along . the international monetary fund , the american department of justice , and anti-poverty ngos all joined in opposing vulture funds are revealing . but so , too , is the court ’s decision , which apparently assigned little weight to their arguments .

typically , this principle implies that marginal tax rates should be similar at different levels of labor income , for different kinds of consumption , outlays today versus tomorrow , and so forth . from this perspective , a shortcoming of america ’s individual income-tax system is that marginal tax rates are high at the bottom ( owing to the testing of welfare programs ) and the top ( owing to graduated-rate structure ) . thus , since 2009 , the government has moved in the wrong direction , sharply raising marginal tax rates at the bottom ( by dramatically increasing transfer programs ) , and , more recently , at the top ( by raising tax rates on the rich ) . one of the most efficient tax-raising methods is america ’s payroll tax , for which the marginal tax rate is close to the average rate ( because deductions are absent and there is little graduation in the rate structure ) . cutting payroll tax rates in 2011-2012 and making rate schedules more graduated ( on the medicare side ) were mistakes from the standpoint of efficient taxation .

the report – the product of a few months of debate within the german foreign-policy and security community – identifies germany ’s current values and interests as a commitment to “ human dignity , freedom , democracy , the rule of law , and the international order that is based on universal norms . ” as gauck proclaimed , germany ’s “ overriding strategic objective ” must be the “ preservation and continued adaptation of this order . ” to achieve this objective , germany must become a “ shaping power , ” a state with the capacity to solve problems and resolve conflicts affecting all or part of the international community . the traditional determinants of states ’ power relative to other states – geography , demography , economic heft , and military might , combined with the availability of resources and technological proficiency – remain important ; but they are often insufficient to confer actual influence in international politics . shaping power builds relationships and invests in institutions that enable it to work well with others , and to create and mobilize “ coalitions and networks of like-minded states . ”

princeton – the largest unresolved issue in the european union is mobility . the integration process was intended to make it easier and more attractive for europeans to move from one country to another . according to this vision , the eu ’s inhabitants had the nation to lose and the continent to gain . but some recent election results indicate that they are more worried about losing the nation . ever since the european single act of 1986 removed restrictions on working in other member countries , the continent has been the single labor market – at least in theory .

london – current antibiotics are becoming increasingly ineffective , not only in the fight against common illnesses like pneumonia and urinary tract infections , but also at treating a range of infections , such as tuberculosis and malaria , that now risk becoming incurable . with g-7 leaders committed , in a recent joint declaration to tackle “ antimicrobial resistance ” ( amr ) , it is time for the more inclusive g-20 – and for china , as it chairs the group for the first time – to take the fight to the next level . failure to address amr will affect everyone , regardless of their nationality or their country ’s level of development . indeed , by 2050 , ten million people could die as a result of amr , up from around 700,000 today , with china and india each housing some one million sufferers . at that point , an estimated $ 100 trillion in global gdp will already disappear .

beijing – measured by the percentage of people living in its cities , china ’s urbanization rate currently stands at around 48 % , according to official statistics . given that the share of urban dwellers in the city ’s urban areas was only 18 % just 30 years ago , this is remarkable progress . but it is still unsatisfactory , because most other countries at a similar stage of development experienced faster urbanization than industrialization . china ’s urbanization lagged behind its industrialization , which now stands at around 70 % , when measured by the percentage of the labor force , whose income derives mainly from non-farm activities . another striking difference between china and some other developing countries is that chinese cities , large and small , lack any sign of significant urban poverty or slums .

berkeley – central insight into macroeconomics is the fact that was known to john stuart mill in the first third of the nineteenth century : there can be a large gap between supply and demand for pretty much all currently produced goods and services and types of labor if there is an equally large excess demand for financial assets . and this fundamental fact is the source of big trouble . a normal supply gap and demand for some subset of currently produced commodities is not a serious problem , because it is balanced by excess demand for other currently produced commodities . as industries suffering from insufficient demand shed workers , industries benefiting from surplus demand hire them . the economy is rapidly rebalances itself , and thus returns to full employment – and does so with a configuration of employment and production that is better adapted to current consumer preferences .

washington , dc – just over 100 years ago , the united states led the world in terms of rethinking how big business worked – and when the power of such firms should be constrained . in retrospect , breakthrough legislation – not just for the us , but also internationally – was the sherman antitrust act of 1890 . the dodd-frank financial-reform bill , which is about to pass the american senate , does something similar – and long overdue – for banking . prior to 1890 , big business was widely regarded as more efficient and generally more modern than small business . most people saw the consolidation of smaller firms into fewer , large firms as stabilizing development that rewarded success and allowed for further productive investment .

berlin – it has been 30 years since the united nations food and agriculture organization launched the tropical forestry action plan , the first global intergovernmental initiative to halt forest loss . since then , deforestation has continued unabated , and the latest international effort to stop it – an initiative known as reducing emissions from deforestation and forest degradation ( redd + ) – looks no more likely to be effective . far from protecting the world ’s forests , the most notable outcome of the two agreements has been , ironically , the production of the expensive consultancy reports . redd + has been created as part of the un framework convention on climate change , and the agreement governing its implementation is expected to be finalized during the un climate change conference in paris . but if world leaders are serious about halting forest loss , they should instead abandon redd + and replace it with a mechanism that addresses the underlying drivers of large-scale deforestation .

beijing – forty years ago this month , china ’s leaders set the country on a path of reform that produced history ’s most dramatic economic transformation . mao zedong died two years earlier , in 1976 , and deng xiaoping succeeded in stamping his vision of economic development and modernization on the third plenum of the eleventh central committee , held in december 1978 . in the four decades since , china has transformed itself into an economic powerhouse , portending an equally momentous makeover of the global economy and geopolitics . china ’s reforms began in agriculture , where the crushing burden of state controls has been relaxed . through the dual-track pricing mechanism , farmers have been given market incentives .

how victims remember trauma is the most controversial issue facing psychology and psychiatry today . many clinical trauma theorists believe that fighting , rape , and other terrifying experiences are seemingly engraved in the mind , never to be forgotten . others disagree , arguing that the mind can protect itself by banishing memories of trauma from awareness , making it difficult for victims to remember their most horrific experiences until it is safe to do so many years later . while acknowledging that trauma is often all too memorable , these certain clinical trauma theorists assert that a condition known as “ traumatic dissociative amnesia ” leaves a large minority of victims unable to recall their trauma precisely because it was so overwhelmingly terrifying . but these clinical trauma theorists do not argue that “ repressed ” or “ dissociated ” memories of horrific events are either inert or benign .

rome – prices of many staple foods increased dramatically during 2007-2008 , creating a food crisis for many poor and developing countries . international prices for maize , rice , and wheat , for example , reached their highest levels in 30 years , causing political and economic instability – and leading to food riots – in many countries . several factors contributed to the crisis , including high oil prices , high demand for crops from bio-fuel industries , falling global stockpiles of food commodities , and lower cereal output . strong economic growth and expansionary monetary policies boosted the trend further , as did protectionist measures , such as export restrictions . while these factors undoubtedly put upward pressure on food prices , they alone can not explain steep hikes .

race has always been a provocative subject when the needs of science and statistics intersect with politics . now that debate is heating up again in france , as the planned introduction of “ ethnic statistics ” has created a fierce dispute that touches the very heart of french republicanism . according to a law that dates back to the french revolution , and reconfirmed in 1978 , french government officials are forbidden to collect information about citizen ethnic or racial origins , real or alleged when conducting a census or other efforts to rally statistical information on the population . there are two main reasons for this . the first is the republican principle enshrined in the us constitution , which recognizes only citizens , and accepts no distinction among them , owing to origin , race , or religion .

detection means determining whether an extreme event is part of routine weather fluctuations or a symptom of deeper , long-term change . attribution means the ability to assign likely causes of events to human activity or other factors . new science of detection and attribution sharpenes our knowledge – and also gives us even more cause for concern . several studies in the last year have shown that scientists can indeed detect long-term climate change in the rising frequency of extreme events – such as heat waves , heavy rains , severe droughts , and intense storms . by using cutting-edge climate models , scientists not only detecting long-term climate change , but also attributing at least some of the extreme events to human causes .

axelrod held tournaments among the major game theorists and political scientists to identify the most effective approach in a repeated prisoner ’s dilemma game . the winner – the strategy most likely to produce a cooperative outcome – was anatol rapoport ’s tit-for-tat ( tft ) strategy . according to the tft approach , a bilateral game should start with cooperation : if the other player behaves cooperatively , so should you . only if the other player defects – that is , begins to display non-cooperative behavior – should you do the same . of course , when the other player cooperates , it might be tempting to defect , in order to increase your own payoff and potentially even secure a windfall .
