in the lonely crowd , the american sociologist david riesman identified three broad cultural types : the tradition-directed cultures that look to inherited rituals , morals , and values for guidance ; the inner-directed culture in which people behave according to self-nourished values ; and other-directed cultures that react predominantly to external norms and peer influences . riesman ’s framework has special resonance in the arab world today , where rising literacy rates and rapid advances in communication technology have stirred the maelstrom of competing cultural narratives , with its three types competing to define the region ’s future . ironically , it is the combination of increased literacy and modern technology that fanns the flames of conflict between the two types of “ reformers ” – religious revivalists and western-oriented modernizers . taking advantage of their ability to mass-produce and instantly disseminate ancient religious texts and western-originating literature , the two camps are fighting for the hearts and minds of otherwise traditional societies . according to the lebanese publisher samar abou-zeid , however

on the global level , it is difficult to argue that inequality is one of the world ’s major political-economic problems . it is hard , at least for me , to envision alternative political arrangements or economic policies over the last fifty years that would transfer any significant portion of today ’s wealth to today ’s rich nations to today ’s poor nations . i can easily envision alternatives , such as the post-world war ii communist victories in italy and france , that would now have impoverished nations in the rich north . i can also envision alternatives that would enriched poor nations : deng xiaoping became china ’s leader in 1956 rather than 1976 , that would have done the job there . but the alternatives that would have made the south richer at the price of reducing the north ’s wealth would have required a wholesale revolution in human psychology .

washington , dc – this month , european citizens will head to the polls to elect the european parliament ’s 751 members to represent 507 million people . the way the election campaign unfolded marks a small but significant step in the emergence of the first transnational political space in europe – indeed , the world – of history . to be sure , the european parliament elections have brought smaller shares of voters to the polls : 43 % in 2009 , compared to almost 60 % in 1978-1994 . nonetheless , the participation rate over the past decade is comparable to the average turnout in american congressional elections . given the perceived remoteness of the european parliament and widespread frustration with the european bureaucracy , the level of participation , and movement toward supranational politics , is remarkable .

but whether europe as a whole avoids losing decades of economic growth remains hangs in the balance , and depends on whether southern european governments can quickly restore competitiveness . the process by which southern europe became uncompetitive in the former was driven by market price signals – by the incentives that those signals were created for entrepreneurs , and by how entrepreneurs ’ individually rational responses played out in macroeconomic terms . northern europeans with money to invest were willing to lend on extraordinarily easy terms to those in the south who wanted to spend , and ample pre-2007 spending made employers there willing to raise wages rapidly . as a result , southern europe adopted an economic configuration in which its wage , price , and productivity levels made sense only so long as it spent € 13 for every € 12 that it earned , with northern europe financing the missing euro . northern europe , meanwhile , adopted wage and productivity levels that made sense only as long as it spent less than one euro for every euro it earned .

shanghai – after decades of spectacular expansion , china faces the difficult task of managing a soft economic landing . naysayers abound , but never mind them . china has the advantage that other countries in today ’s troubled global economy lack : a clear path forward . if china carries out a sustained , comprehensive effort to raise productivity , it can address its growth challenges , reduce the risks of financial crisis , and complete its shift to a consumption-driven , high-income economy with a large and affluent middle class . if it does , its annual gdp could be an estimated $ 5 trillion larger by 2030 than it is likely to be if policymakers continue to pursue investment-led growth .
london – as governments across western europe have begun bailing out banks and their depositors , eastern europeans have watched nervously , unsure of what the global financial storm would mean for them . now that the storm has hit , the fragile bonds of european solidarity are being tested . two countries – hungary and ukraine – have already been asked for large support packages . several more could do so over the next month if frozen credit markets do not thaw . if the situation continues until the end of the year , which can not be ruled out , many more countries could experience severe banking crises .

a closely coordinated effort by amongst private and public-sector partners to deliver oral polio vaccines to every child under the age of five was the key to success . globally , international donors and un agencies have worked closely with national governments , tallying the precise needs of massive polio immunization campaigns aimed at reaching hundreds of millions of children . last year alone , the global polio eradication initiative delivered nearly two billion doses of polio vaccine to 575 million children in 94 countries . in each country , partner institutions , including the world health organization ’s minister , unicef , other un agencies , service groups like rotary international , representatives from donor governments , the private sector , and non-governmental organizations , jointly and carefully planned each immunization campaign . every detail , from the number of bicycles and boats needed to deliver the vaccine to otherwise inaccessible areas , refrigerators , and cold boxes needed to keep the vaccine potent , even the batteries needed to power them , were counted and budgeted .

florence – europeans eager to revive the continent ’s unification process have lately turned their attention to the united states ’ founding . many , however , reject america ’s precedent on the grounds that today ’s problems are too dissimilar from those encountered then . others , who accept that federalist principles might well fit the problems of a european common market , despair that the “ european people ” who could bring about this new political structure are missing . but there are striking parallels between america ’s founding years and europe ’s ongoing political and economic crisis . in fact , the creation of the american constitution and the birth of the american people offer reasons to hope that some of the most difficult issues facing europe can one day be resolved .

left-wing proponents of so-called modern monetary theory argue that larger permanent fiscal deficits are sustainable when monetized during periods of economic slack , because there is no risk of runaway inflation . following this logic , in the uk , the labour party has proposed “ people ’s qe , ” whereby the central bank would print money to finance direct fiscal transfers to households – rather than bankers and investors . others , including mainstream economists like adair turner , former chairman of the uk financial services authority , have called for “ helicopter drops ” : direct cash transfers to consumers through central-bank-financed fiscal deficits . still others , such as former fed vice chair stanley fischer and his blackrock colleagues , have proposed a “ standing emergency fiscal facility , ” which would allow the central bank to finance large fiscal deficits when a deep recession hits . despite differences in terminology , all of these proposals are variants of the same idea : large fiscal deficits monetized by central banks should be used to stimulate aggregate demand in the event of another slump .

cambridge – government programs to support pensioners are in trouble in every country , owing to rising life expectancy and rising retirement ratios to taxpayers . the problem will worsen in the years ahead as the adverse demographic trend increases the fiscal burden of financing pensions and health care . the problem is uniquely different in the united states , because america ’s “ trust fund ” system of social security financing will create a crisis when the fund is exhausted . though the options at that time will be different from the choices that other governments face , policies to avoid america ’s crisis are relevant to other countries that confront population aging . here is how the american system works : a payroll tax is dedicated exclusively to financing retiree benefits .

florence – british politics has always been something of an experimental laboratory for the industrialized world . in the 1970s , britain was where the preeminent postwar model of how to manage the economy collapsed . that model was based politically on the creation of consensus , and economically on keynesian demand management . today , the equivalent collapse was of an “ regulation-lite ” regime , in which a party that styled itself as “ new labour ” accepted a powerful role for markets – particularly in largely deregulated financial markets . in the 1960s , keynesian policies delivered the illusion that everyone benefited , with high levels of employment and significant wage growth .

austin – living in a city turns you into a cannibal . that , at least , is the metaphor preferred by jean-jacques rousseau , who considered cities a pit of human corruption . rousseau was so convinced of the malign effects of urbanization that he “ would rather see men grazing on meadow grass than devouring each other in cities . ” urbanization inures people to the suffering of rural communities , and , as townspeople crowd together , their capacity for compassion toward others atrophies . urbanites become the kind of people ready to sacrifice one another to satisfy their appetites : cannibals .

at least four “ mismatches ” lay at the root of past global financial crises , with three plague china today . first , with its bank-dominated financial system , china ( along with europe and many emerging economies ) suffers from maturity mismatches , owing to short-term borrowing and long-term lending . yet , unlike many emerging economies , china is not battling a currency mismatch , owing to its large foreign-exchange reserves and persistent current-account surpluses , which force it to become a net lender to the rest of the world . but china has not avoided the third mismatch , between debt and equity : the credit-to-gdp ratio doubled in the last decade , from around 110 % in 2008 to 220 % in 2017 , highlighting china ’s under-developed long-term capital and equity markets . nor can policymakers afford to ignore the fourth mismatch – between ultra-low nominal interest rates and relatively higher risk-adjusted return on equity ( roe ) for investors – that has helped to fuel speculative investment and widening wealth and income inequality .

technological innovation and demographics are now headwind , not tailwind , for growth , and financial engineering can not save the day . the aberrant period in history is the hundred or so years after the american civil war , during which breakthroughs in energy , electrification , telecommunications , and transportation fundamentally reshaped societies . human lives became markedly more productive , with life expectancies rising dramatically . between 1800 and 1900 , the global population grew more than 50 % , and then more than doubled over the next 50 years , with economies growing much faster than in previous centuries . by the late 1970s , growth began to slow in many advanced western economies , and us president ronald reagan and federal reserve chair alan greenspan ushered in a debt cycle that supercharged activity .

berlin – the way we eat in the industrialized world is unhealthy , unjust , and unsustainable . far too much meat consumed is produced under questionable ecological , ethical , and social conditions . and now our industrial model for meat production is being exported to the global south – especially india and china – where meat consumption is rising among these countries ’ emerging middle classes . worldwide , 300 million tons of meat are produced each year , with the united nations food and agriculture organization estimating that the annual figure will increase to 455 million tons by 2050 if demand continues to grow at current rates . such large amounts of meat can be produced on an industrial scale alone , at a high social , political , and ecological costs .

london – “ shorting ” is a tactic well known among financial coreds . it means betting against an asset with borrowed money in anticipation of profit when its value goes down . a speculator can “ short ” a government by borrowing its debt at its current price , in the hope of selling it later at lower prices and pocketing the difference . for example : on january 1 , 2010 , i think i am about to be up soon for greeks . i borrow at face value , € 10 million of the greek government ’s 2016 bond , which then trades at € 0.91 , from goldman sachs for six months .

the economic challenges facing developed-country middle classes are largely the result of two factors : rapid white - and blue-collar routine jobs to automation , and a shift in middle - and lower-value-added jobs to lower-labor-cost countries . the latter pattern depressed incomes and wage growth not only in the tradable sector directly , but also in the non-tradable service sectors , owing to the spillover of displaced labor . the result was surplus labor conditions in the middle – and the lower-middle-income ranges , not dissimilar to early-stage surplus labor in developing countries , where it suppresses income growth ( for a period of time ) even as the economy expands . a decline in bargaining power for labor and a falling real minimum wage may also have contributed to income polarization , though these are probably secondary factors . though the challenges facing the middle class are well documented , american leaders have largely failed to recognize fully the struggles of middle-class households , much less implement countermeasures .

economic development in the gaza strip was limited under egyptian rule , with the region suffering the burden of absorbing palestinian refugees fleeing fighting in the southern territories of mandatory palestine , which would later become israel . palestinians ’ access to egypt was restricted , and much of gaza ’s largely unskilled labor force was dependent on the un relief administration , which built and maintained local refugee camps . the 1967 war placed all mandatory palestine ( as did sinai and the golan heights ) under israeli military occupation . nevertheless , though one-third of the west bank was closed to palestinians to make room for a few thousand jewish settlers , only 10 % of its predominantly rural population was refugees , many owned their land , and a variety of jobs were available . by contrast , 70 % of gaza ’s population comprised refugees living in difficult conditions in refugee camps scores and largely depended on work in israel .
the second draft of history is often written by keynesian people themselves . after world war ii , winston churchill confidently argued that history would treat him kindly , because “ i propose writing that history . ” when the financial crisis erupted , the same thinking may have crossed the minds of hank paulson , ben bernanke , and tim geithner , who was us treasury secretary , chairman of the federal reserve bank and president of new york fed chair , respectively . all three published lengthy memoirs explaining why they did , and did not , what they did and did not do – inevitably , with a degree of self-justification in each case . now , a decade later , the three co-authored what might be described as a version of 2.1 that episode ’s history .
the goal was not to address the problems they faced directly , but to induce new , more efficient activities that would help to turn debt into assets and maximize the economy ’s capacity . in this sense , east asian economies embraced the process of “ creative destruction ” described by the austrian economist joseph schumpeter , whereby the economic structure is constantly revolutionized from within . moreover , by implementing incremental reforms that facilitate – and even encourage – the replacement of old , inefficient sources of growth with new , more dynamic ones , they expedited this process . for example , in the 1980s , china ’s productivity-enhancing agricultural reforms spurred partly growth in the non-agricultural sector , a result of policies aimed at stimulating township and village enterprises . similarly , in the 1990s , china addressed the buildup of bad debt and unfinished construction projects – the result of state-owned enterprises ’ chronic loss-making and excessive property investment , respectively – by implementing the institutional reforms that stimulated growth in more dynamic sectors , thereby offsetting soes ’ declining return on capital .
brussels – as protests over china ’s crackdown in tibet and the debate over kosovo ’s unilateral declaration of independence continue to fester , the injustice of taiwan ’s ongoing international isolation has barely stirred a flicker of interest , despite taiwan ’s recent presidential election and a referendum on united nations membership . this neglect is not only shortsighted ; it may also prove dangerous . this seeming double standard can be explained partly by a sense of guilt : the west , for the most part , embraced kosovo ’s independence in an effort to assuage its own culpability for not preventing slobodan milosevic ’s campaign of ethnic cleansing there . similarly , much of the world is protesting in the name of tibet , because countless millions have witnessed china ’s brutal suppression of tibetan culture . on the other hand , taiwan does not capture our attention , because it is stable and prosperous economically .

palo alto – since the sixteenth-century science of toxicology was developed , its guiding principle has been that “ dose makes poison . ” it is a rule that applies to the medicines used by patients worldwide many billions of times a day . the right dose of aspirin can be therapeutic godsend , but consuming too much can be lethal . the principle even applies to foods : large amounts of the “ axis of the monetarist ” or licorice are notoriously toxic . the risk that substance poses broadly depends on two factors : its inherent capacity to inflict harm and one ’s exposure to it .

liquidity injections and low interest rates have microeconomic effects that have received little attention : they lower the cost of capital vis-à-vis labor costs , which causes a relative decline in demand for labor . this is very likely to exacerbate the unemployment problem ; it is certainly not mitigating it . one solution is to channel part of the liquidity injections toward countering this factor-cost asymmetry . thus , for every $ 100 of new liquidity , the us could use $ 60 to purchase assets , and the remainder to give firms a marginal job-creation subsidy , which could be especially efficient in economies with flexible labor markets that enable short-term hiring . even if the employment subsidy were offered only for , say , one year , firms would be tempted to use more labor during this time .

new york – attempting to revive the world economy while simultaneously responding to the global climate crisis has raised knotty questions : are statistics giving us the right “ signals ” about what to do ? in our performance-oriented world , measurement issues have taken on heightened significance : what we measure affects what we do . if we have poor measures , what we strive to do ( say , gdp growth ) may actually contribute to worsening living standards . we may also be confronted with false choices , seeing trade-offs between output and environmental protection that do not exist . a better measure of economic performance , by contrast , might show that steps taken to improve the environment are good for the economy .

madrid – economic globalization , together with a rebalancing of power between the world ’s north and south , has made developing countries and many companies within them , key global economic actors . this provides a new rationale for strengthening the international framework to protect foreign investment . once upon a time , global foreign direct investment flowed from only a few sources : traditionally affluent states of europe , north america , and japan . but cross-border investment from countries like brazil , india , and china is now flowing not just to other emerging and transition economies , but also to the “ old ” fdi-exporting states . these changes have increased the complexity of the international investment regime , and it should broaden interest in developing a more effective investment-protection framework .
worries about globalization and the computer revolution ultimately boil down to the same thing , because globalization is mostly the product of new information technology . computers and the internet have made information almost costlessly available , and they can do business across cultures and continents . the worry is that information technology is now on the bend of a “ hockey stick ” curve , where it will suddenly take off at much greater speed than it has before . the resulting changes will not all be welcome in economic terms . hockey stick curves often occur in nature .
copenhagen – amid a surge of concern about climate change , many countries – including brazil , australia , the united states , and the european union ’s members – passed laws in the 2000 ’s , or severely restricting access to incandescent light bulbs . the intent was understandable : if everyone in the world exchanged most light bulbs for energy-efficient compact fluorescent light bulbs ( cfls ) , we could save 3.5 % of all electricity , or 1 % of our co2 emissions . the current attempt by republicans in the american congress to roll back america ’s effort to ban incandescent bulbs revived this discussion . many contend that the agenda is being driven by knuckle-dragging climate-change deniers . but it is worth looking at the premise that banning things is the smartest way to tackle global warming .

but diaspora potential economic significance goes well beyond remittances . as the late historian philip curtin documented , from the start of urban life , millennia ago , trade typically involved networks of co-ethnic merchants living among aliens . greeks , phoenicians , trans-sub-saharan traders , hanseatic league , jews , armenians overseas chinese , and dutch and british east indian companies organized much of the world trade through such networks . although these alien traders were sometimes politically powerful in host countries , they were often weak and faced with discrimination . the economist avner greif argues that these co-ethnic networks ’ durability and resilience throughout history reflect their ability to enforce contracts at long distances when the existing institutional framework could not do so reliably .

japan has a strong international reputation when it comes to managing natural disasters . but the “ perfect storm ” of the largest earthquake and tsunami since industrialization , and the resulting meltdown of three reactor cores at the fukushima daiichi plant , went beyond any scenario previously envisaged . japan ’s national government and local communities had no emergency plan for the situation that they faced in contaminated areas , resulting in ad hoc responses marked by inefficiencies and poor communication , particularly with regard to radiological risk . despite such problems , effective measures were implemented to evacuate those at risk , limiting potential hazard from contaminated foodstuffs . local communities initiated immediate decontamination of sensitive areas outside evacuated zones ( such as kindergartens and schools ) , in tandem with efforts by japan ’s atomic energy agency ( jaea ) to develop remediation technology within these zones .

washington , dc – not long ago , the separation of financial supervision and monetary policy was in vogue in many countries . some countries – like the united kingdom and australia – went so far as to unbundle these functions by assigning responsibility for financial stability to specialized agencies and extricating their central banks from financial supervisory issues altogether . in the aftermath of the global financial crisis , however , financial supervision and macroeconomic management were forced to reunify . this rapprochement is a consequence of the growing recognition that asset-price cycles must be taken into account both for macroeconomic management and financial supervision . prior to the crisis , asset-price cycles were viewed by many as essentially harmless or at least as a relatively insignificant monetary-policy channel .
seoul – if you chase two rabbits at once , the old saying goes , both will flee . and yet this is precisely what many governments are obliged to do : pursue both growth and distributional fairness . the two goals , however incompatible , are entirely different from one another , and few policy tools can simultaneously help to achieve both . this idea matters a lot in trade policy . much theoretical and empirical research demonstrates that opening trade can spur a country ’s gdp growth .

attempts by economists to predict the future have had mixed results , at best ; very few foresaw the depth of the great recession , even after it had already started . the trouble lies in the fact that many of the leading indicators used to measure the economy rely on out-of-date , incomplete , or flawed data . forecasters , for example , calculate real gdp based on initial monthly estimates of quarterly gdp – a statistic that is often revised significantly as more data become available . as a result , forecasts lag behind reality . during the third quarter of 2008 , fewer than 30 % of forecasters who contribute to a survey of professional forecasters predicted a decline in gdp in the remaining months of the year ; in fact , gdp plunged more than 8 % in the fourth quarter of 2008 , one of the largest drops on record levels .

new delhi – there is something about the number of five in sino-indian relations . asia ’s two giants have long defined their relationship with respect to the famous panchsheela : mutual respect for each other ’s territorial integrity and sovereignty ; mutual non-aggression ; mutual non-interference in each other ’s internal affairs ; equality and mutual benefit ; and peaceful co-existence . now , china ’s new leaders have enunciated a new panchsheela , with president xi jinping offering a “ five-point proposal ” for sino-indian relations . updated principles would maintain strategic communication and sound bilateral relations ; harness each other ’s strengths and expand cooperation in infrastructure , investment , and other areas ; deepen cultural ties and enhance mutual understanding and friendship ; expand coordination and cooperation in multilateral affairs to safeguard developing countries ’ legitimate interests and address global challenges ; and accommodate each other ’s core concerns and reconcile bilateral disagreements amicably . india would be happy to embrace each of these principles .

at the international monetary fund ’s annual meeting in october , the fund ’s chief economist , olivier blanchard , fueled controversy by pointing out that in recent times , governments tended to underestimate the adverse growth consequences of fiscal consolidation . they typically assumed that cutting public spending by the dollar would reduce gdp by 50 cents in the short term ; by blanchard , the true outcome in current conditions is the $ 0.90-1.70 decline . that is a large gap , but also a perplexing finding : how can there be so much uncertainty ? contrary to what such forecasting disparities may suggest , economists actually know a lot about the consequences of fiscal policy , at least far more than they used to know . until the 1980 ’s , it was routinely assumed that the so-called “ multiplier ” – the debt-to-gdp ratio to change in government spending – was stable and larger than one .

cambridge – this year ’s nobel prize in economic sciences went to george akerlof of the university of california at berkeley , michael spence of stanford university , and myself for our work on the “ asymmetry of information . ” what is that work about , and why did we commit it ? for two hundred years , economists used simple economic models that assumed that information was perfect – i.e. , that all participants had equal and transparent knowledge of the relevant factors . they knew that information was imperfect , but hoped that a world with moderate imperfections of information would be akin to a world with perfect information . we showed that this notion was ill-founded : even small imperfections of information could have profound effects on how the economy behaved .

a contemporary non-medical writer described the qualities of intense pain as including extreme unpleasantness , the ability to annihilate complex thoughts and other feelings , the ability to destroy language , and the strong opposition to objectification . she reminds physicians that for a person suffering intense pain , what dominates awareness above all else is a powerful negative emotion . most of the time , pain occurs after simple nerve endings detect tissue injury in various ways , generating signals that travel to spinal cord and from there to brain . for many years , researchers thought that these signals traveled along a few well-defined routes to reach relay stations in the brain called thalamus . from there , researchers believed that signals went to part of the brain ’s cortex , which managed body awareness , somehow turning them into conscious experience .

rome – in 2010 , global leaders achieved the millennium development goal ( mdg ) of reducing the proportion of the world ’s poor to half its 1990 level – five years ahead of schedule . but rising unemployment and falling incomes underscore the enduring threat of poverty worldwide . after all , poverty is not an unchanging attribute of a fixed group ; it is a condition that threatens billions of vulnerable people . despite their shortcomings , income measures are useful in gaining a better understanding of the scale of poverty and vulnerability worldwide . but the world bank ’s poverty line of $ 1.25 per day ( in purchasing-power-parity terms ) , which is used in measuring progress toward the mdgs ’ poverty-reduction target , is not the only relevant threshold .

new york – like an inmate on death row , europe has received another last-minute stay of execution . it will survive a little longer . markets celebrate , as they have after each of the four previous “ european crisis ” summits – until they come to understand that fundamental problems have yet to be addressed . there was good news at this summit : european leaders finally understood that the bootstrap operation by which europe lends money to banks to rescue sovereigns , and sovereigns to rescue banks will not work . likewise , they now recognize that bailout loans that give new lender seniority over other creditors worsen private investors ’ position , who will simply demand even higher interest rates .
munich – the german constitutional court has delivered its long-awaited decision on the european central bank ’s “ outright monetary transactions ” program . since its launch in 2012 , the omt program has allowed the ecb to buy , if necessary , unlimited amounts of troubled eurozone countries ’ government bonds , provided affected countries subscribe to european rescue fund rules , the european stability mechanism . thousands of germans appealed to the constitutional court against the omt program , arguing that it violates article 123 of the treaty on the functioning of the european union , which bars monetary financing by eurozone governments and imposes substantial risks on german citizens as taxpayers . the court has now declared that it fully endorses the plaintiffs ’ arguments , and that the omt program does indeed violate eu primary law . but , rather than issuing a formal ruling that would constrain the bundesbank and the german parliament , as it could , the court has asked the european court of justice for its opinion .

true , the quality of democratic governance can sometimes be augmented by the reduction of discretion of elected representatives . well-functioning democracies often delegate rule-making power to quasi-independent bodies when issues at hand are technical and raise distributional concerns ; when log-rolling would otherwise result in sub-optimal outcomes for all ; or when policies are subject to myopia , with heavy discounting of future costs . independent central banks provide an important illustration of this . it may be up to elected politicians to determine the inflation target , but the means deployed to achieve that target are left to central bank technocrats . even then , central banks typically remain accountable to politicians , and must provide accounting when they miss the targets .
first , it is important to realize that a strong and overly volatile currency is not just the central bank ’s problem of fixing . while the central bank bears a good part of the responsibility , it needs support from other parts of the government , most notably from the finance ministry . maintaining a competitive currency requires a rise in domestic saving relative to investment , or a reduction in national expenditure relative to income . otherwise , the gains in competitiveness would be offset by rising inflation . this means that the fiscal authorities have a large responsibility : target a structural fiscal surplus that is high enough to generate the space needed for a real exchange-rate depreciation .

beijing – is china poised to surpass the united states to become the world ’s largest economy ? the international monetary fund recently predicted that the size of china ’s economy would overtake that of the us in terms of purchasing power parity ( ppp ) by 2016 . but a recent co-authored study by robert feenstra , an economist at the university of california , davis , shows that global economic leadership would pass to china in 2014 . and , more radically , arvind subramanian of the peterson institute of international economics argues that china actually surpassed the us in ppp terms in 2010 . purchasing power parity measures a country ’s income using a set of international prices applied to all economies .
but one should not jump to conclusions . a balance of energy imports and exports is only the first approximation of independence . as i argue in my book the future of power , global interdependence involves both sensitivity and vulnerability . the us may be less vulnerable in the long run if it imports less energy , but oil is a fungible commodity , and america ’s economy will remain sensitive to shocks from sudden changes in world prices . in other words , a revolution in saudi arabia or a blockade of the strait of hormuz could still inflict damage on america and its allies .

munich – discussions are now underway to establish a system of joint deposit insurance for eurozone banks . proponents of the scheme , with the european commission and the european central bank ( ecb ) taking the lead , point out that deposit insurance would avert the risk of runs on banks in times of crisis . while this argument is true , critics emphasize the mismatch in risk , owing to the high proportion of bad loans on banks ’ balance sheets in some countries . to address this risk mismatch and move ahead with the plan , balance sheets will have to be cleaned up before considering the next step . while the share of bad loans for stable eurozone countries ’ banks is just 2 % , the most recently published international monetary fund statistics , from last april , show a 11 % share for ireland , 16 % for italy , 40 % for cyprus , and 46 % for greece .

berlin – more than a year into the arab revolts , their outcomes remain highly uncertain . but some initial lessons for international politics – and for western , particularly european , foreign policy – merit serious consideration . almost everyone was surprised by the revolts , even though the underlying political and socioeconomic causal factors were well known . as is often true in crises that become systemic , we knew phenomena , but failed to grasp their interactions , partly because politicians and analysts are reluctant to anticipate ruptures : the familiar is held to be stable even when it is known to be problematic . proteins that retain the same function across very different species – generally the case with orthologs – are expected to keep the same fold . but the sequence of amino acids that make up protein chains in these orthologs can vary dramatically . sometimes the extent of sequence identity between two orthologs can be as low as 25-30 % , and yet their folds remain strikingly similar , attesting to the robustness of the function of evolutionary change . this conservation of protein fold across species makes the origins of our complexity even more puzzling , as it is well known that the number of human genes deceptively small , merely one order of magnitude larger than that of , say , rice . if the structure of proteins is conserved across species where is our complexity coming from ?

tokyo – with japan ’s economy struggling to escape its deflationary torpor , the economic-revitalization plan initiated by prime minister shinzo abe in 2012 has come under growing scrutiny . but japan ’s current travails , which brought the concomitant decline in japan ’s stock market , stem from the yen ’s appreciation – 24 % over the past year – against major currencies . “ abenomics ” – which included substantial monetary and fiscal expansion – has nothing to do with it . since abenomics was introduced , japan ’s labor market has improved considerably : 1.5 million new jobs have been created , and the unemployment rate has fallen to just over 3 % . moreover , corporate profits have soared , with tax revenues rising by more than ¥ 20 trillion ( $ 188 trillion ) .

barcelona – after world war i , when millions of european civilians were made refugees , forced out of their homelands by enemy occupation or deportation , the international regime was developed to coordinate effective responses and ease the suffering of those uprooted . a century later , another refugee crisis is underway , and this time it is europe that has the power to provide safe haven to desperate people . yet it has not risen to the occasion , with many of its responses failing to match the urgency of the situation . in just the first few months of 2015 , more than 38,000 people have attempted to reach europe by crossing the mediterranean from north africa . some 1,800 people have died as a result – more than twice the number of such deaths in all of 2013 .

milan – the word “ openness ” has two related but distinct connotations . it can mean unrestricted , accessible , and perhaps vulnerable ; or it can mean something , like a person or institution , is transparent , as opposed to secretive . the first meaning is often applied to trade , investment , and technology ( though most definitions do not match the opportunity with vulnerability ) , which have always driven structural economic change , especially with respect to employment . structural change can be simultaneously beneficial and disruptive . and policymakers have long had to strike a balance between an abstract principle of openness and concrete action to limit the worst effects of change .

freer trade across borders reduces income disparities . for example , the 2015 white house report found that a ten-percentage-point drop in tariffs leads to a one-percentage-point drop in the gender wage gap , and that lowering tariffs also reduces wage gaps based on race and immigration status . moreover , increased openness to trade is associated with lower infant mortality rates and higher life expectancy , especially in developing countries . over time , free trade enables workers to shift to more efficient industries , resulting in higher wages , increased infrastructure investment , and a more dynamic economy . most powerful of all , free trade underpins economic growth , which means that millions more people lifted out of poverty .

according to a 2005 declaration of principles of international election observations , credible monitoring requires that five criteria be met . first , observers must be autonomous – financially and otherwise – in their relationship to the host country . second , observers must be granted unrestricted access to all aspects and phases of the election process , as well as to all the technologies involved . third , observers must face no constraints in meeting with all the authorities and political actors . fourth , observers must not be subject to any pressure or threat of retaliation by any government .

for example , in carrying out manhattan project ( to produce the atomic bomb during world war ii ) and the first moon landing , the american government set a remarkable technological goal , established a bold timetable , and committed the financial resources needed to get the job done . in both cases , scientists and engineers delivered on time . the example of atomic bombs might seem unpleasant , yet it raises an important question : if we ask governments and scientists to cooperate on war technology , should we not do at least the same to save the planet from carbon pollution ? in fact , the process of “ directed technological change , ” in which bold goals are set , milestones are identified , and timelines are embedded , is far more common than many realize . the information-technology revolution that brought us computers , smart phones , gps , and much more , was built on a series of industry and government roadmaps .

washington , dc – millions of the world ’s poorest people face severe water-related challenges – from lack of access and shortages to disputes over supplies – with profound implications for security , economic development , and environmental sustainability . as world leaders design a development agenda to succeed the millennium development goals ( mdgs ) , which expire in 2015 , addressing these issues should be a top priority . consider this : almost one billion people worldwide lack access to safe drinking water , and 2.5 billion lack adequate sanitation . the costs are staggering : thousands of child deaths every day , with annual economic losses estimated at $ 260 billion – more than double the total amount of official development assistance . making matters worse , climate change will render water supplies more unpredictable , with increasingly frequent and intense floods and droughts imposing significant human and economic costs and impeding development in poor countries .

zurich – repeatedly in recent years , calls for a revival of civilian nuclear power have been called for . yet that renaissance never seems to be coming . indeed , of the world ’s more than 200 countries , only 30 use nuclear power . in july 2010 , a total of 439 nuclear power plants with a net installed capacity of 373.038 gw ( e ) were connected to various national electricity grids , some 1.2 gw ( e ) more than at the beginning of 2006 . roughly 16 % of total energy needs ( up to 25 % in the highly industrialized countries ) are now met by electric power .
denver – the united states constitution , which turned 225 years old last summer , is a remarkable document : the provisions of the text written in the eighteenth century continue to guide twenty-first-century governance . we will be reminded of the implications of this coming weeks , as president barack obama fills senior positions in his second-term administration . in many cases , the process will not be pretty . article ii of the us constitution stipulates presidential powers that require the senate ’s “ advice and consent , ” including the nomination of senior us officials . probably no one , 225 years ago , had any idea that the number of officials deemed to require senate confirmation would ultimately surpass 1,400 , or that senate confirmation would involve a vetting process that often takes years to complete .

hypothetically , switching off lights for an hour would cut co2 emissions from power plants around the world . but , even if everyone in the world were cutting all residential lighting , and this translated entirely into co2 reduction , it would be the equivalent of china pausing its co2 emissions for less than four minutes . in fact , earth hour would cause emissions to rise . as the united kingdom ’s national grid operators have found , a small decline in electricity consumption does not translate into less energy being pumped into the grid , and therefore will not reduce emissions . moreover , during earth hour , any significant drop in electricity demand will entail cutting co2 emissions during the hour , but it will be offset by the surge from firing coal or gas stations to restore electricity supplies after that .

one strangest claim made in debates about social insurance now roiling the world ’s richest countries is that government-funded defined-benefit pension programs ( such as america ’s social-security system ) are outmoded . these programs were fine , the argument goes , for the industrial economies of the great depression and post-world war ii generation , but became obsolete in today ’s high-tech , networked , post-industrial economy . advocates of this argument propose a different model . just as corporations today are much happier supporting workers ’ pensions by contributing to employees ’ private accounts , so governments should offer ( or require ) contributions to privately owned accounts . the value of these accounts would fluctuate rather than rest on a defined-benefit scheme that guarantees a fixed real sum of resources on available retirement .

new york – there was a remarkable similarity between european central bank president mario draghi ’s statement after a recent meeting of the ecb governing council and us federal reserve chair janet yellen ’s first congressional testimony : “ we can not know that their policy decisions will take into account only domestic conditions . ” in other words , emerging-market countries , though subject to significant spillover effects from advanced economies ’ monetary policies , are on their own . this confirms what emerging-country authorities have known for some time . in 2010 – following the fed ’s announcement of the third round of quantitative easing – brazilian finance minister guido mantega accused advanced countries of waging a global “ currency war . ” after all , advanced economies ’ policies were driving large and volatile capital flows into major emerging markets , pushing up their exchange rates and damaging their export competitiveness – a phenomenon that brazilian president dilma rousseff later referred to as a “ capital tsunami . ”

geneva – the recent sharp spike in food prices and growing concern about food security have sparked anxiety worldwide . the possibility of being unable to put food on the table fills parents with a deep sense of foreboding . and , because the world ’s poorest people spend a higher share of their income on food , they are the worst affected , raising the risk that years of progress in reducing poverty could be reversed . seemingly unalterable factors generating these record-setting increases in food prices – a shift toward higher protein diets in many countries , growing populations , greater use of biofuels , and climate change – suggest that elevated food prices are here to stay . in the absence of solutions that alleviate growing pressure on supplies , hunger , and malnutrition will increase .

london – vulnerable communities are facing the brunt of climate change – from rising sea levels and extreme weather events to prolonged severe droughts and flooding . according to the world bank , without effective mitigation measures , climate change could push more than 100 million people into poverty by 2030 . to help the most vulnerable communities become more resilient to the effects of climate change , financial institutions should support small and medium-size enterprises . in emerging economies , smes account for as much as 45 % of employment and up to 33 % of gdp – and these numbers are significantly higher when informal small and medium-size enterprises are included . when the sme builds on its own climate resilience , it can cascading effects in communities around it .
cutting methane is actually cheaper than cutting carbon . and because methane is a much shorter-lived gas than co2 , we can prevent some of the worst of the short-term warming through its mitigation . agricultural production accounts for half of anthropogenic methane , but wastewater systems , landfills , and coal mining also create gas . professor claudia kemfert of the german institute for economic research ( diw ) argues that spending $ 14 billion to reduce methane would generate benefits – from reducing warming – between 1.4 and three times higher . we could also place a bigger focus on reducing black carbon , considered responsible for as much as 40 % of current net warming and one-third of arctic melting .

today , few know where the term “ globalization ” originated . the oxford english dictionary gives as the earliest reference to its current usage of the 1972 academic article . the word was used earlier , but in a rather different sense . it was a diplomatic term conveying the linkage between disparate policy areas ( for example , in negotiating simultaneously on financial and security matters ) . the oed etymology ignores the non-english origins of the term , which can be found in the inventive linguistic terminology of continental european student radicalism .

the increase in the monetary base , however , is only temporary ; when bonds are redeemed , it reverts to its former level . this eventual need to reduce the monetary base is an implicit claim on the central bank ’s assets ; thus , the increase is rightly viewed as a liability for its balance sheet . under a money-financed fiscal stimulus , however , the central bank never has to reverse the increase in the monetary base . because holders of the distributed money have no central bank claim , the monetary base should not be viewed as a liability , but as an increase in the central bank ’s net worth . in other words , helicopter money is not an interest-free loan to the government ; it is a gift .

but that rule succumbed rather quickly to violent money-demand shocks , even though friedman ’s general argument – that a credible commitment to low inflation requires favoring rules over discretion – remains very influential . inflation targeting was best known as the rule that instructed central banks to set – and try their best to achieve – a target range for the annual change in the consumer price index ( cpi ) . close cousins included targeting the price level instead of the inflation rate , and targeting core inflation ( cpi minus volatile food and energy prices ) . there were also proponents of flexible inflation-targeting , who held that it was fine to place some weight on short-term real gdp growth , so long as there was a clear longer-term target for cpi inflation . but some felt that if the definition of it were stretched too far , it would lose its meaning .
firms in advanced economies are now cutting jobs , owing to inadequate final demand , which has led to excess capacity and uncertainty about future demand . but cutting jobs weakens final demand further , because it reduces labor income and increases inequality . because a firm ’s labor costs are someone else ’s labor income and demand , what is individually rational for one firm is destructive in the aggregate . the result is that free markets do not generate enough final demand . in the us , for example , cutting labor costs has sharply reduced the share of labor income in gdp .

cambridge – the nineteenth-century physicist heinrich hertz once described his feeling that james clerk maxwell ’s equations depict the fundamentals of electricity and magnetism , “ have independent existence and intelligence of their own , that they are wiser … even than their discoverers , that we get more out of them than was originally put into them . ” not long after , albert einstein called niels bohr ’s atomic model “ the highest form of musicality in the sphere of thought . ” more recently , the late nobel laureate richard feynman described his discovery of new laws of physics , declared , “ you can recognize truth by its beauty and simplicity . ” similar sentiments are all but universal among modern physicists . wishful thinking could never produce working iphones , pluto photographs , or atomic bombs .
why , with clear formulated alternatives on the table , did the government choose a predictably disastrous course of action at such a high human cost ? there are three possibilities : ignorance , intent , and strategic interaction . let ’s start with the last one . in a 1991 paper , allan drazen and alberto alesina suggested that economic stabilization might be delayed , because two contending groups are trapped in attrition wars ; all understand that adjustment is necessary but expect the other group to bear the brunt of the cost . by delaying , they provide information to the other group about their willingness to withstand the pain .

countries where english is not lingua franca are particularly disadvantaged in science , not because they lack academic excellence , but because english-language journals call the shots . non-english academic journals simply do not command the same attention in the science community . as a result , the extent of research topics that many countries can commit is limited , and they must struggle to retain scientific talent . this is particularly true in the middle east , where governments struggle to diversify their economies to make them more resilient . as english-language empirical-research journals consolidate their hold on channels that determine whether or not a scientist will have a successful career , developing countries will have to invest heavily in their own data infrastructure to place domestic researchers on a more competitive footing .

berlin – the task for the world in addressing north korea ’s saber rattling is no easier to do by confronting an impoverished and effectively defeated country . on the contrary , it is in such circumstances that calm foresight is most necessary . the genius of the habsburg empire ’s prince klemens von metternich in framing a new international order after the napoleonic wars was that it did not push a defeated france into a corner . although metternich sought to deter any possible french resurgence , he restored france ’s prewar frontiers . by contrast , as henry kissinger argued , the victors in world war i could neither deter a defeated germany nor provide incentives to accept the treaty of versailles .
sometimes dating a recession is a judgment call . america had a brief , sharp recession in 1980 , followed by a long and severe one in 1981/1982 . many economists believe that it was one major episode , and that is probably the appropriate way to think about it in a broader historical context . but the economy did indeed grow in the interim – just barely enough to consider distinct recessions . and , because they were separated by a shift from president jimmy carter to president ronald reagan , it was politically consequential that two recessions were identified .

beijing – china ’s annual gdp growth slowed to 7.6 % in the second quarter of 2012 , down from 8.1 % in the first quarter and the lowest growth rate since the second quarter of 2009 . the newly released growth data may have dispelled fears of a hard landing for china , but nonetheless prompted many to argue that china must stimulate its economy further to guarantee 8 % annual growth . since early 2010 , to contain inflation and property bubbles , the chinese government has tightened monetary policy . as a result , inflation fell from june to 2.2 % , a 29-month low , and house prices , for which the national bureau of statistics unfortunately stopped issuing official data , seem to be stabilizing , and may even have fallen modestly . to be sure , the slowdown in china ’s growth rate reflects the government ’s success in fueling the real-estate bubble , as well as other official policies aimed at rebalancing the economy .

the problem is that the principle can not be applied consistently . a world in which we live is a small garden of well-examined territories surrounded by dim and dark forest of disasters . disasters lurking in distance are legion : disaster-related and comets ; world-wide pandemics and plagues ; nuclear and non-nuclear wars ; droughts , famines , and floods ; volcanic eruptions , earthquakes , and tsunamis ; human over-population and non-human extinction ; rising temperatures and sea-level ; falling temperatures and spreading ice ages ; depletion of clean air and water ; disappearance of forests , farms , and fish . all of these disasters – and many others still imagined – are possible , and many are unacceptable . the precautionary principle prescribes action , regardless of cost .

from the 1960s to 1970s , those writing about the netherlands often lamented the “ dutch disease . ” there were so many generous subsidies , grants , and transfer payments – aimed at all against the truly needy artists unable to sell their work – that after-tax wages often barely outweigh the benefits . so people rarely returned to work after they lost or left jobs , or did so in the underground economy with its unreported cash payments . whether one considered the dutch welfare state humane and generous or bloated and foolhardy , its largesse took a heavy toll on the economy . but , unlike , say , the french , the dutch have responded to their past excesses with a set of policies designed to promote a return to work in the formal labor market .

new york – when i was a bright-eyed eighth grader in my native sri lanka , i could not wait for my first sex education class . in our early teens , my classmates and i were as curious as we were clueless about sex and sexuality . yet , instead of receiving reliable answers to pressing questions about our bodies , relationships , and sexuality , we were simply handed a book , told to read a particular chapter , leaving to figure things out on our own . millions of young people around the world have similar experiences , often with serious adverse consequences . following its targeted killing of iran 's second most powerful leader , the us could well find itself with no alternative but to devote more military resources to the middle east , a path that could lead to additional iranian provocations .
after all , iran and the us have already been at war for decades , and neither side has an interest in an uncontrolled military escalation now . as in previous years , project syndicate asked its commentators to offer their best guesses about the events and trends that will define the coming 12 months . if there is one common theme in this year 's selection , it is that what happens in 2020 will weigh on the present for many years to come . regardless of how facebook ’s own digital-currency moonshot , libra , fares , it has already provided a wake-up call for firms and policymakers around the world . “ if revolution there is to be , let us rather commit it than undergo it , ” otto von bismarck once said .
four decades after the “ nixon shock , ” no one disputes that china has benefited enormously today , the impoverished and autarkic country that nixon visited is history . global reintegration has turned china into an economic powerhouse . it is the world ’s largest exporter in volume . china ’s presence is feeling around the world , from mines in africa to apple stores in the united states . as we reflect on china ’s remarkable progress since 1972 , it is also an opportune time to consider how china continues to fall short in overcoming systemic impediments to long-term success .
a significant chinese slowdown may already be unfolding . us president donald trump ’s trade war has shaken confidence , but this is merely a downward shove to an economy that has already been slowing as it makes the shift from export-led – and investment-led growth to more sustainable domestic consumption-led growth . how much the chinese economy will slow is an open question ; but , given the inherent contradiction between an increasingly centralized party-led political system and the need for a more decentralized consumer-led economic system , long-term growth could fall quite dramatically . unfortunately , the option of avoiding a consumer-led transition and continuing to promote exports and real-estate investment is not very attractive , either . china is already a dominant global exporter , and there is neither market space nor political tolerance to allow it to maintain its previous pace of export-led expansion .
the arab world faces serious problems that can be met only with more flexible , democratic political systems . the second arab human development report , issued in 2003 , underscores the close relationship between the arab world ’s educational shortcomings and its lack of democracy . democracy requires an informed citizenry able to question its government . a well-educated citizenry is also essential if young men and women are to acquire the skills needed to perform the kinds of jobs that today ’s global and competitive world demands . alas , instead of progress , what we see is a cycle of inadequate educational opportunity , leading to a lack of economic opportunity .
the president threatened to destroy turkey ’s economy if it does what it enabled to do . with the kurds – most of them civilians – fleeing turkish bombs , the un security council has remained typically silent , while europeans have condemned everything and all involved . as foreign-policy disasters go , this is one for record books . but the seeds for this larger conflagration have been sown long before the now-infamous trump-erdoğan call . absent any coherent policy , conditions have been ripe for crisis .
but a “ tobin ” program – a fanciful idea when milton friedman proposed it in 1969 – would also be a radical departure for policymakers , requiring an abundance of prudence about citizen and investor perception , confidence , and solid governance structures . and such an approach would cement the notion that central bank policy is “ the only game in town , ” relieving elected government leaders of their responsibility for pro-growth policies and the fiscal choices they control . a less risky and time-tested route to stimulating demand would be a major increase in debt-financed public infrastructure investment . it is well documented that europe and the united states have underinvested in infrastructure . from a macroeconomic perspective , infrastructure investment is a “ twofer ” – it strengthens productivity and competitiveness in the long run , and where unused capacity is available , boosts demand , output , and employment with a significant multiplier effect in the short run .
with the government losing $ 4.5 billion every year by subsidizing passenger fares , it has little money to spend on upgrading infrastructure , improving safety standards , or speeding up trains . as a result , railways run out of money before they run out of plans . in the last 30 years , only 317 of the 676 projects that parliament has been sanctioned have been completed , and it is difficult to imagine how the railways will acquire the estimated $ 30 billion needed to complete the remaining 359 projects . and if all of this were not bad enough , india ’s leadership seems not to recognize the challenges that railways present . in a country where rail passengers can not even expect a clean toilet , let alone on-time arrival , prime minister narendra modi has spoken of introducing bullet trains – the latest in a string of irrationally grandiose aspirations .
under federalism – whether cooperative or “ uncooperative ” – it is often assumed that state and local governments pursue the same goals . in fact , there is a deep divide between left-leaning “ blue ” cities and right-leaning “ red ” states , where many are located . and there are many ways that state governments can thwart progressive federalism at the municipal level . cities , for their part , often lack the information and resources needed to develop and implement effective policies . a number of organizations have now emerged to strengthen city governments ’ policy-making capacity , including michael bloomberg ’s government innovation program , fuse corps , results for america , social finance , third sector capital partners , and usafacts .
we need to look beyond these figures to determine who is truly responsible for fomenting a political climate where blatant lies and explicit racism and bigotry have entered the mainstream of public discourse . only when we identify the sources of the odious virus now afflicting our democracies can we take practical steps to quarantine them . let ’s start with the “ patient zero ” in this political plague : rupert murdoch . for decades , this impresario of the right-wing political-entertainment complex has coarsened politics in the uk and the us – not to mention his native australia – for profit and political influence . murdoch ’s newspapers and television networks might just as patented a recipe for deceitful , dog-whistle politics that powered trump ’s rise and brexit vote .
